review_title: How could this possibly be boring and forgettable?
review_detailed_main:
I'm the exact target audience for this movie. I'm a sci-fi junkie, I love thrillers, Adam Driver is awesome, and I'll watch basically anything with large scary creatures. This should have been a layup for me to like. Yet I found myself unengaged and somewhat bored. I started feeling sleepy even after a Red Bull.

I don't really know how or why it happened, but this is just a forgettable movie. Some dumb things happen but I am able to turn my brain off. Although after watching the Angry Joes review, I didn't realize how many dumb things I ignored. I guess I just didn't care enough to notice them.

I hope a movie like this doesn't discourage studios from going for more of these mid-budget movies. I like the idea of an isolated story somewhere random in space/time. I just hope they do a better job next time. (1 viewing, opening Sunday 3/12/2023)

review_title: A committed Driver lifts this slightly above the pack
review_detailed_main:
I really think this film would be doing much better at the box office with a better title and clearer marketing. This is a more than serviceable action thriller starring a legitimate star that is mostly entertaining for its 90 minute runtime.

The CGI is surprisingly good given the small budget and it's cool seeing dinos in a non-Jurassic Park film. The story is probably the weakest element given its cliched beats and real Last of Us vibe. Some wooden dialogue and lack of exposition round out my critiques. I liked the futuristic tech in the film and Driver delivers an expected solid showing. 65 won't light the genre on fire, but it's better than it's getting credit for.

The Good:

Awesome recreation of a wild dangerous world full of dinosaurs and threads of death and struggle for survival. The suspense and fear is better than Jurassic Park.

Really cool Sci-fi tech featured, really awesome play on someone (Driver) struggling to survive a primitive world while also having highly advanced technology, but still facing challenges Top-notch cinematography, lighting, and CGI makes you feel very immersed into the world and situations

The Bad:

The plot is extremely basic and predictable. Man faces a few obstacles that he overcomes, most of them the same situation, that's about it. There's only two characters basically, and the dialog between them is limited. This works for a bit, but there's not enough development of the characters, and it's easy to just not care about what happens to them one way or another.

It could have been much better if there was more objectives in the plot, more characters or build up, more on what happened before and after the situation on the planet.

Easily had more potential than what was served up. I was really looking forward to this when I seen the trailer but this had next to 0 marketing..one thing that did attract me was Sam Raimi was producing so instantly it got my attention. The CGI is so mixed one minute at the beginning it's like watching the BBC walking with Dinosaurs program that was released around 20 years ago but the CGI middle to end is good? It's like they kept the budget for the big finale but there isn't a lot of Dinosaurs in this, so if you're going with tye expectations of seeing a lot of Dinosaurs you won't get it. There's a period in the middle of the film were it just sort of trudges on with not much happening. I personally would watch it again but I won't be in a rush to and I'm highly disappointed they didn't do better in every department..story action and CGI.

... a cry of joy that the titles had started to roll, that the end had finally arrived, although with such poor editing throughout you can't be fully confident that the end is the end, but checking the elapsed time, and knowing that these days the credits can often run for at least ten minutes (or more) I knew that the torture was over, that I could refrain from saying and thinking wtf more times than any recent film I can remember, while musing on why such a talented 2-dimesnional actor like Adam Driver would undertake a role like this in a film that is so poorly scripted, so dismally directed, containing two cardboard characters so full of chore. This is not a good piece of filmmaking but, as many observers often suggest, it could have been so much more.

The plot is updated and integrated themes from various older ones, but it works. The CGI is well done and feels right. The interaction between the two primary characters is well done and they connect .

Adam Driver plays the role very well as the clinical , angry pilot. Yet warm and caring as time goes on.

Ariana Greenblatt plays the role of a scared child , who is confused about what is going on. She also brings some humor to the movie. Her acting is superb . One minute she is a scared little girl , the next she is making fun of Adam .

I enjoyed it, then I love survival movies. So this is a perfect movie for me.

review_title: Where Do Review Snobs Come From? ¯\_(~)_/¯
review_detailed_main:
I DUNNO!

This is a decent film in my opinion. I give it a 6.5 stars.

A transportation pilot carrying passengers suspended in a cryogenic sleep finds himself stranded on an unknown planet after colliding with debris from an uncharted asteroid belt. Only he and a child survive the crash but they are miles from their only escape pod and they aren't alone.

Adam Driver gave a good performance, the story was interesting and the special effects were good. I'm not much of a sci-fi buff but the tech and weaponry created for the film were good too.

Admittedly, the film could have had a faster pace and more action. I think if it fails anywhere that would be my complaint but it was a decent film regardless.

I don't really understand all the hate but everyone is entitled to their own opinion. It may not be for everyone I suppose but I know that I'll likely watch this again at some point.

review_title: We thought "how bad can it be?"
review_detailed_main:
The answer is, pretty bloody awful. We've watched this on the day Leeds United got beaten 5-1 at home by fellow no-hopers Crystal Palace and I'd rather watch a repeat of that than a replay of '65'!

Dull, cliche-ridden flat storytelling. 0<1 dimensional characters and development. Tediously slow set pieces with trite dinosaur protagonists. God, such dull scenes: one after the other of averagely generated CGI monsters.

And, the pseudo-daughter can't communicate meaningfully with the main character? You have to extract a very, very good performance to make that scenario work. Adam Driver is very bland in this too.

review_title: 5.7/10? Am I the only one who enjoyed this?
Not Jurassic Park, but at least it's not After Earth
review_detailed_main:
I was very curious about this film since it seemed very simple in concept to those of some of the best movies in the past decades. Not to mention having phenomenal actor Adam Driver fighting dinosaurs, who wouldn't watch it? After finishing the movie, I can at least say the movie was a competent and engaging watch, but wasn't as exciting as the trailers made it out to be.

First of all, Adam Driver is fantastic in this movie. Despite the simplistic and somewhat predictable narrative, he's still engaging to watch as a desperate man trying to survive and rescue the only other survivor, a young foreign girl. And Props to Ariana Greenblatt for pulling off a helpless girl with a language opposite of the lead and still having good chemistry.

Other than that, the movie doesn't really utilize it's concept that well with the battle of scientific technology and prehistoric creatures. There are only a few instances where we can see him use strategy and the use of various gadgets to take them down. While those scenes are fun, it's very little throughout the movie.

I was worried that this movie could have been awful since it gave me very similar vibes to After Earth, and I'm sure you don't need me to explain why. But I can at least say that writer and directors Scott Beck and Bryan Woods didn't drop the ball that badly. I can also respect that they want to bring Hollywood back to basics with concepts that are simple, yet effective. While slow paced, and at times underwhelming, I can at least say I enjoyed myself while watching.

review_title: More plot holes than the roads in Pennsylvania
Adam Driver shines in this interesting sci fi movie.
review_detailed_main:
Pilot Mills crash lands on a hostile planet whilst his ship is damaged in a heavy meteor storm, when he completes a reconnaissance on the inhospitable world, he discovers dinosaurs, and a young survivor.

I didn't really have high expectations going in, but on the whole I rather enjoyed it. I would say it's a fairly effective monster film, I wouldn't go in hoping and looking for a sweeping sci fi saga, it is pretty much a man Vs monsters movie.

Production values are actually pretty good, and the dinosaurs look very effective. The destruction of the planet scene was awesome, and I guess that was a novel take on what happened on the planet.

I enjoyed the relationship between Mills and Koa, the language barrier made it interesting, credit to both actors for ensuring there was a good deal of chemistry between the pair.

I never expect to see the likes of Adam Driver in a film like this, but the versatile actor that he is, delivers once again, I thought he was excellent.

Unusual, interesting, engaging.

7/10.

A valiant attempt by the director to see just how many cliches can be stuffed into 90min.

The opening sequence was quite beautiful, yet the moment the storytelling started, o boy, did I suspect we're in for something special. The writing and dialogue is like my 10 year old self got a few million dollars and sent off to make a movie. I cannot fathom how professional writers, people who do this for a living, crafted this debacle.

I love sci-fi. I love big monsters. I love movies.

And somehow, I was borderline asleep while watching the amalgamation of all three. To all those reading, I implore you, send help. Hollywood is in a state of disaster.

review_title: This is a worthwhile addition to the science-fiction, action genre in a Pitch Black kind of way
review_detailed_main:
65 (2023) is a movie that my wife and I saw in theaters this evening. The storyline follows a pilot on a research voyage whose ship runs into an unforeseen asteroid belt and crashes on Earth 65 million years ago. Most of the crew doesn't survive the crash except one little girl who doesn't speak English. The pilot and the little girl try to make it across the planet to a rescue pod that can hopefully get them home.

This movie is cowritten and codirected by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods, who also worked together in Haunt, and stars Adam Driver (House of Gucci), Ariana Greenblatt (Love and Monsters), Chloe Coleman (My Spy) and Nika King (Euphoria).

There's a lot to like about this movie but there's also something missing. The storyline had a ton of potential but needed more details of the backstory on a macro scale rather than just the characters sub plots (which were good). I think we needed more details on the reason for the voyage and who the pilot worked for. I will say the storyline does keep you interested from beginning to end, it just could have been better. The acting and chemistry of Driver and Greenblatt was perfect. The special effects are outstanding and as good as any Jurassic Park movies. The dinosaurs and insects were a 10/10, though they could have worked in a few passive dinosaurs, a herbivore or two. Every creature in this movie is a blood thirsty killer. The action scenes are intense and there's some great jump scares throughout the film. The settings and cinematography was very good, the CGI was outstanding and the wounds are gory and intense. The ending is predictable but still entertaining.

Overall, this is a worthwhile addition to the science-fiction, action genre in a Pitch Black kind of way. I would score this a 6.5/10 and recommend seeing it once.

First off, I love Jurassic Park. I grew up with it at my grandma's house. For that reason I love dinosaur movies in general because we don't get a lot of them. I saw "65" at an early release and I thought it was great. It wasn't everything I hope it would be but the acting was fantastic, special effects were top tier, and the story was good for a predictable sci-fi. Adam Driver does an incredible job and helps immensely with the sci-fi suspense. All in all, it'll be a movie that will be forgotten over the years but definitely deserves the appreciation and recognition now. Great pre-summer movie.

The movie was alright. Graphics were good and acting was fine as well, but somehow I felt it didn't make the connection it supposed to. Too bland. The thrilling moment didn't make me sit in anticipation that what will happen. I usually like these kinds if movie, but this was just okay. It wasn't bad and most will enjoy it. Good movie for theatre. Whole family can go, but I felt something missing.

Acting was good by all.

Story was simple and simply told Action was good Not that gripping.

Duration was fine of the movie.

I do recommended watching in the cinema. It is better enjoyed there. I guess I had more expectation from Sam Raimi film.

The story is the well worn tale of castaways reaching a destination against time and various challenges & adversaries.

It is so cliched that it may well have been written by a computer A. I. The story is so incompatible with logic, realism or probability , yet so full of the same old unconvincing ideas we've seen thousands of times , that is actually a painful experience for me to endure. Thank goodness for the fast forward button.. if I was in the cinema I would have left after 30 minutes.

This film is in the Jurassic Park mould of sciFi horror- basically a simple horror story made in the action genre. The sci fi trappings just allow lazy writing in dealing with the dilemmas faced.

Like many horror films the protagonist(s) in this just can't help doing the wrong thing, or doing the right thing the wrong way.

I lost count of the ceaseless daft actions and occurrences- whatever could go wrong does go wrong.

Here are just some glaring ones- Adam Driver's spacecraft has no warning or defence systems to detect or mitigate meteorites, asteroids and other space debris- it only notices a field of them minutes before impact. It doesn't alert the sleeping Adam, It then does an analysis of potential danger- ignores any danger; and 30 seconds later continues right into the middle of the meteorite field .... and says - 'warning UNEXPECTED meteor activity' after the first impacts.

Why has his craft only got one pilot and no other personnel ?

Why did the ship and meteorite make peculiar 'creaky door dinosaur sounds' during the impacts ...

When the cryogenics fail why doesn't the craft implement a retrieval process ?

Everything in the ships personnel apartments was colourless, and the many ships computer screens only had red & blue graphics.

When the meteorites teat a hole in the craft why doesn't it decompress / suck all the contents out into space? Why are the cryogenics units on the outside walls of the craft?

Adams character doesn't originally send a distress signal,deleting it instead... Then he goes off to kill himself.

He shows no humour or empathy with the girl- in fact his character is very peculiar. The story tries to mawkishly tell you why via his daughters video messages.

When you fall from a tree on your back you are winded and temporarily immobilised... the way he fixed his dislocation was unbelievable - as was the state of his wound and lack of attention to healing it.

He tells the girl to run when confronted with fast running 'dinosaurs'.

He takes no sleeping bags , tent, food & drink...toilet roll , insect net or replant ?

Nor his daughters video diaries, spare flash light (also never used to strobe & dazzle the creatures) or his suite & helmet.

The 12 kilometer journey (7 & a half miles) would take 4-8 hours depending on the terrain. If it was 12 miles as the crow flies then Adams computer should have estimated a more realistic distance.

When in the cave there's a tunnel they don't seem to have noticed when they set up camp. When attacked they retreat into the tunnel and a big deal is made of finding another exit- why ? Why not just wait until the threat outside moved on.

By this point I gave up counting and fast forwarded with subtitles.

It didn't matter what happened anymore- DEJAVU took over.

review_title: Lots of potential, not enough dinosaurs
Maybe not the best sci-fi movie ever made but pretty entertaining

review_detailed_main:
This is nowhere near a perfect movie. That being said, it's nowhere near trash either. Amazing cinematography, cgi and acting take this film a long way. In the days where mediocre 200 million marvel movies have swallowed cinema, this is honestly a breath of fresh air. I have missed watching lower budget standalone action films that don't require any external knowledge of the audience in order to understand the plot and are just a fun 90 minute watch.

So I suppose that even though this is not a perfect movie it's a new original idea and that's all I want to see from cinema nowadays. It is the direction that will bring the industry to light and maybe let it evolve (which will not happen if all the studios release reboot after reboot for the next decade)

review_title: This is one of the most conventional movies I've seen in a while
review_detailed_main:
This movie is predictable. Like very predictable. But that's not the best one-word depiction you can come up with. I would stick to "conventional" - since there are predictable movies (any of the middle and final Jurassic delivers are predictable, but you can find some 20 minutes of excitement here and there), but this one is conventional. The story is there but it's conventional, the action is there but it's conventional... take the cave scene for example. The set up is somehow promising - that thing in the shadows. But then... just 15 minutes of... boooring. Not sure if it's about the story, the script, the direction, the acting... I just didn't care, didn't engaged, didn't guessed.

Only thing I liked a bit was the score. Like an OST that could stand on it's own. But I'm not even sure about this at this point.

review_title: Starts out rough, but sticks the landing.
review_detailed_main:
Like Beck/Woods' earlier writing effort A Quiet Place, 65 is a surprisingly small-scale thriller that boasts simple ideas and familial themes. Although I think the former was crafted with considerably more skill and had a more polished, tight script, the latter is still pretty effective at what it sets out to do.

We're granted some clumsy exposition and an overly long set-up at the film's start, but once the journey actually begins, it's rather exciting till it's end.

I loved that Mills and Koa spoke different languages and thus had to communicate mostly non-verbally. It added a great deal of weight to their interactions and emphasised just how much trust and emotion can be built and shared without words.

Many small character moments are shown throughout the film and they do end up building to a sweet, heartfelt conclusion, but Beck/Woods' script didn't really tie these individual moments together very well.

The screenplay needed some more work to clean up the often wooden dialogue and to build a thread that the movie's individual scenes could follow. Because with how simple this film's plot is, it really shouldn't feel like it's meandering as much as it is.

But what I mostly came for is the dinosaur action. Like I said earlier, it takes too long to get to these parts, but when they do come they're worth the wait.

Each dinosaur encounter is unique in how it's dangerous and how it can be handled, which kept the action fresh. And each of these sequences is also appropriately directed, with the characters' positions made clear and their peril understood.

I had a good time with this film. It's got its moments when it really shines, though I wish it had been rewritten so it could have been truly memorable.

review_title: Young girl screaming, Adam Driver Pew Pew.

review_detailed_main:
Who comes up with this stuff? Who approves it? They want you to think that 65,000,000 years ago, in a distant universe, people talk. Look, dress, act, and otherwise are virtually identical to 2023. I undrestand you can cut costs if you do it that way, but you lose all credibility.

Talk about cutting costs, I think most of the "creatures" were taken from the Jurassic lot. I saw no originality here.

Then there's the "acting". Adam Driver is simply not good enough to consume pour attention for 90 minutes. Nothing about him is that interesting or provocative, or whatever it takes to stare at a screen for 90 minutes. The little girl is a breath of fresh air, but it doesn't help.

review_title: Imagine a more visceral and brutal Jurassic Park/World with a hefty dose of Turok mixed in and you get this surprisingly awesome Sci/fi Action.
review_detailed_main:
This was personally my most anticipated first release of the year being a sucker for Sci/fi and anything creature related so I gladly went to the early screening. It feels like its gotten barely any marketing and most likely won't be in theaters long, but it has a chance to become an interesting entry in the genre . This is mainly thanks to writers/directors; Beck and Woods who know how to craft an intense creature feature (A quiet place1/2).

The story borrows a bit from the mentioned properties, but manages to still maintain an independent feel. It's still written well and has ambitious visions put forth. The scenery and visuals are epic in in every sense of the word. Adam Driver showcases that he can be the main man in large scale action film which is very unexpected but welcomed. The creature design to me is the standout and what I show up for. It blows the last JW trilogy out if the water in that facet as well as the incredible action.

Overall this is my kind of release and while it may not due massive numbers I'm glad crazy sci/fi is still being made for the big screen.

review_title: If you want to watch Adam Driver shoot dinosaurs, you found the right movie
review_detailed_main:
You'd be hard pressed to find a lamer trailer that was released so far in 2023 than the trailer to "65" - even Adam Driver couldn't save the monstrosity of mediocrity that was the official preview. And yet, I'd be lying if I said the trailer didn't peak my interest, even if it was just out of the sheer ludicrousness of the film's concept; I mean, you're telling me that a movie starring Kylo Ren fighting dinosaurs is soon to be released, and it's not hitting theatres in January? Say no more, I'll be there opening night - and I was.

Sitting in a surprisingly full theatre, myself and around 70 other people found ourselves watching the 7:25 p.m. Showing of "65." The energy was palpable, and even though my stomach was hurting from the milkshake I drank 15 minutes prior, I was pretty darn excited to see Adam Driver shoot some dinosaurs. And truth be told, I got that and even a little bit more. You see, "65" isn't a great film, but it can be an entertaining one.

After an admittedly rocky start with some pretty bizarre editing choices, the movie picks up the pace once Driver crash lands to earth and meets Koa, played by Ariana Greenblatt. A little girl who doesn't speak the same language as our main character, Koa and Driver form a pretty adorable bond, especially through their attempts at communicating that can lead to some pretty funny scenarios. I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed their chemistry, and their relationship throughout the film was a big part of my enjoyment of it.

But if you're going to see this movie, you're going for the dinosaur action - do you get it? Yes and no. There is definitely a fair amount of action in this movie; Adam Driver gets plenty of opportunities to blow dinos to bits with his futuristic rifle, and it's pretty entertaining to watch. However, a lot of the action takes place in the night time, which greatly frustrated me because, as you can imagine, that meant that a lot of the action was obscured by the darkness. I know this is a strategic move on the studios part to save money, but dear god, would it kill them to shell out a bit more cash so I can watch dinosaurs get blown to pieces in the daylight? This is by no means an action fest, either - there is a lot of character building between Driver and Koa, more than one might expect if we're being honest, which can slightly take away from the momentum; however, the amount of action this movie contains did satisfy my sci-fi cravings, even though I certainly wouldn't have minded a bit more violence.

I wouldn't call "65" a good movie, but it is an entertaining one - a guilty pleasure, if you will. This definitely had the potential to be better than it ended up being, but for a 90 minute science-fiction action adventure, there's enough here to warrant a Saturday night theatre experience, especially if you've had a few drinks beforehand and just want to chill with a popcorn and a large soda. If you're on the fence about watching this, the question you should ask yourself is: Do I want to watch Adam Driver shoot dinosaurs? If the answer is yes, then you already know you'll find something to like with "65."

review_title: Starts off weak, and believe it or not gets weaker right up until the ending...

review_detailed_main:
I watched "65" yesterday in the cinema.

For what the film wants to be, a survival horror thriller, it can hardly be condemned. It's suspenseful, I was emotionally invested and the chemistry between Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt is good. I also liked the acting of both of them.

The plot is mundane and the character sketch remains fairly superficial, but it's enough to make me grow fond of both of them and root for them. Both have suffered tragic losses in life and thus have a lot in common. However, the plot is unfortunately also predictable in many places. The one or other moment surprised me and went differently than I would have expected.

The logic in the film can be questioned here and there. For example, the ammunition display of Mill's rifle does not decrease at all in the beginning and he shoots a lot with it. At the end, in the final battle, the ammunition gauge suddenly melts away from full to empty. Another criticism is that the famous comet can be seen in the sky both during the day and at night, which is completely illogical since the earth rotates. Either he is to be seen in the day or at night. Both is not possible.

The horror scenes are well done and are oppressive, but unfortunately the film doesn't make enough use of the scary factor. There are also jump scares here and there, but they could have been done without, because I'm not a fan of them. You can scare (almost) anyone, but creating real "creepiness" is much more interesting. I'm more a fan of creepy atmosphere than scary moments.

Another positive thing is the soundtrack by Chris Bacon and Danny Elfman. It is really well done.

I also liked the camerawork and various great wide shots of the landscapes. I like it when movies offer something like that. Of course you can also watch documentaries, but they don't offer an exciting "story".

All in all, I came out of the film quite satisfied.

Rating: 7/10 points

Rewatch value: Low

Emotional depth: Medium

Lasting impression: Low.

65 really could've used a few more Dino focused set pieces to make it really fun but with a tight 90 minute run time, simple premise and a really good double act of final set pieces it remains a good time that thankfully doesn't squander a premise this interesting.

Adam Driver shows he's just as good in these kind of films as he is in his usual dramatic roles, an effortlessly convincing action star whose bond with Ariana Greenblatt is believable thanks to their dynamic more than anything on the page.

Scott Beck and Bryan Woods do a good job with a lower budget, giving the film a sense of scale that undoubtedly exceeded the budget (especially the CG which is surprisingly convincing) and there's some effectively tense moments. The music by Chris Bacon is good with all the expected sci-fi sensibilities.

review_title: 65 million years ago a visitor crash landed on Earth.

review_detailed_main:
A movie that can be considered a "slow" movie and how a story can be interesting without stupid words and stupid dialogues.

We can understand a lot of things of the characters by trying to understand their expressions, their way of moving inside the environment, their way to communicate without saying a word.

It's like a "bildungsroman" in a very little format in which the characters express themselves, understand and try to comfort each other.

It's also a short version of Last Of Us. Obviously, 1h30 is not enough to develop a character, but I think that a movie can demand an effort to the viewer.

Very underrated.

Well, my review was randomly deleted midway through typing, which is really odd, but here we go again... I'm genuinely shocked at the low reviews here.

I'd never heard of this movie, knew nothing of it but it popped on my recommendations. Looked like a silly action movie, so I figured, 'why not'.

Expectations wonderfully exceeded.

It's a simple story, a man protecting a child, with every fiber of his being, with a SciFi backdrop.

It's the epitome of 'show don't tell' movie making and it's done wonderfully.

Turns out, I like Adam Driver! After the Star Wars debacle, I'd written him off, but I've been won over.

He has the physicality and movement for this role, making action sequences believable but he emotes so much, wordlessly. He's excellent at subtle story telling even without lines.

I don't know of the child actress, but she did really well. I was never yanked from the story because of typical 'child actor' issues. She was believable as a stoic, frightened, stubborn young lady.

The CGI isn't great, but not so bad it distracted me from the story, but nothing to write home about, either. The practical effects and locations are more than enough to keep the eyes happy though.

It's a story of a father, a man, trying to survive on multiple levels, and a child dealing with horrible trauma and having to trust a stranger, in a strange land.

And being he was written as a real man, he steps up, and does everything to protect this child and get her to safety.

I miss simple story telling like this. Again, I don't understand the bad reviews, it's such a sweet, heroic movie.

Very touching, nice to see, I hope it does well so we can get more story telling like this.

65 is good with its acting, Scf-Fi elements, and the story. The story having to do with Mills (Adam Driver) and Koa (Ariana Greenblatt) crash landed on an unknown planet with their ship almost destroyed. They must reach their other side of their ship to get out of the planet safe and sound. The adventure to the other side of the ship is quite treacherous because they must look out for unknown territory and dinosaurs along the way.

Overall, I thought it was a pretty good film that starred Adam Driver attacking dinosaurs in it. 65 reminded me of Jurassic Park, but if it were a Science Fiction. A con that I found is that it is pretty slow since most of the film only consists of Mills, Koa, and dinosaurs. It is still pretty entertaining to say the least with it being a dinosaur-survival film and the ending. I would recommend to watch 65 in theaters for a good watch.

review_title: Terrible, did I say it was terrible

review_detailed_main:
Trash movie about 2 people who can't talk to each other running around with a game boy advance pew pewing lizards. If I didn't spend the money on tickets I would have walked out of the movie theaters.

I honestly just can't believe the amount of plot holes in the movie. It was actually so bad my wife and I laughed throughout the movie.

After the movie was over we heard other groups talked about how bad the movie was as well. Saying that the trailer did a good just making it look good. To be honest, I don't even remember seeing the parts in the trailer in the movie. Don't waste your money and save it for Shazam next week.

The important thing about the movie sixty-five is that it says everything that is the condition of reason.

This movie is successful in the field of narration of science and combining imagination and is blindfolded better than last year's awful movie Jurassic World Dominion!

Let me summarize the movie has relatively good special effects and good acting, especially Adam Driver.. We also see some interesting action and complex adventure similar to routine Hollywood films in this key and important production, which we think really managed to achieve its goal to a large extent

I enjoyed watching this fascinating and unknown movie in drama, adventure in IMAX cinema..

...there were two alien visitors from another planet, Somaris. One of them appears to be Caucasian, married with a black lady and a kid back in Somaris, and they all speak American English. Another alien is a girl who also looks exactly like human, speaks no English but a peculiar language of Somaris which the alien guy does not understand at all. Instant One Star Rating.

Highly recommended to fast forward this movie while having a meal so as not to completely waste your precious time, I would consider to give one more star if the movie industry pays dividend to those who watch such movies. Be warned.

As "65" (2023 release; 93 min) opens, we are informed that it is "Prior to the advent of mankind, their civilization explores the heavens", and we get to know the Adam Driver character, Mills. In order to earn extra money for the treatment of his sickly young daughter, Mills volunteers for a 2 year space mission. Alas, wouldn't you know, the spaceship is beset by meteorites and makes a crash landing, on a place called.... Earth, where it is, wait for it, 65 Millions Years Ago! Mills appears to be the sole survivor... At this point we are 10 minutes into the movie.

Couple of comments: this is the latest from co-writers and co-directors Scott Beck and Bryan Woods ("Nightlight"). Nothing wrong as such with wanting to do another Jurassic Park-wannabe dinosaurs action movie, except that the concept and story line in this case is as utterly laughable as it is cringe-worthy. After all that, you'd think that the action scenes are going to blow you away, but that is not the case at all. I suppose that the best news of all is that this clocks in at 93 minutes, and before you know it, the movie has come and gone. I can only hope for Adam Driver that he picked up a nice paycheck for this role, as there is little else good to say about this. Bottom line: made almost 30 years after the original Jurassic Park, we are reminded yet again that a dinosaur action movie is nothing without good story telling, in which Jurassic Park was, and still is, the master.

"65" opened in theaters in March, 2023, and did okay but not great at the box office. It started streaming on Netflix last week, and I just caught up on it the other night. If you are in the mood for a dinosaur action movie, I'd suggest you check this out, with lowered expectations, and draw your own conclusion.

"65" is a surprisingly entertaining film that offers a fun and thrilling ride for fans of dinosaur action movies. Adam Driver delivers a strong performance as the protagonist, a man who may lose everything and is now on a mission to save a young girl in a "post-apocalyptic" world filled with dinosaurs. It isn't really a post-apocalyptic world, but for the sake of this review, that is what we will call it. The movie will explain what's going on in a proper sci-fi manner, which I will not spoil here.

However, despite its strengths, the film does feel somewhat underdeveloped and lacks the depth and emotional resonance of other post-apocalyptic works like "The Last of Us." Additionally, the B-movie vibe of the film may not appeal to all audiences.

The release timing of "65" may also work against it, as it inevitably draws comparisons to "The Last of Us," which is widely considered one of the greatest shows on streaming. The similarities in plot and themes between the two works may make "65" feel like a budget version of "The Last of Us."

Nevertheless, the film's simplicity and engaging characters make it easy to become captivated by the performances and the dinosaur action. It's hard not to be entertained when a movie has dinosaurs, and "65" delivers on that front.

Overall, while "65" has shortcomings, it is still a fun time at the movies for those who enjoy action-packed films with prehistoric creatures.

review_title: Like watching a grade school play
review_detailed_main:
Dinosaurs and Sci Fi have been beaten to death by formulaic Hollywood tools, and this movie is just another nail in the coffin. Combining Prospect and Jurassic Park sounds like a winner on paper, but not when the mission is carried out by some of the worst editors, writers, and directors in modern Sci Fi.

I had to fast forward through half the movie to remain sane. Adam Driver gave his best but no one can make lemonade out of a pile of turds.

Do yourself a favor, skip this on streaming. This movie didn't even last a month in On Demand before the studio decided to cut their losses and sell to Netflix.

review_title: Adam Driver is on fire when confronting dinosaurs
review_detailed_main:
Contrary to what some people think, I personally quite like this movie.

First of all, it's just a 90m movie, I mean what do you expect drama or interesting story in just 90m? For me in 90m the story of the film is very neat, concise, attractive, and not fussy.

Second, this is a purely entertaining movie, you should know what you're going to watch and don't set yourself up to expect something big and then call it a disappointing movie.

Third, the action splash scenes in the movie are so good, you won't be disappointed. Adam's acting is impeccable.

And the last thing, if compared to the movie jurassic world dominion, I think 65 deserves more praise and more revenue than that trash movie.

review_title: Visuals are Alive in 65, But Story Feels A Tad Extinct
review_detailed_main:
LIKES:

The Acting -There is really not a lot of characters in this movie, so the top three are kind of it and they, well, they do a good job for the roles they have been given.

-Coleman has this way of playing these sort of down to earth characters with a lot of things involving more of the peaceful, calm, and sad tones. She pretty much says a lot of the same things in this movie, and like AE, there isn't much more I can say on the repetition.

-Greenblatt, is still quite a talented actress landing the weirdest roles for my viewing. In this one, she plays the scared and yet learning role, but takes a made up language of pulled dialects together and kills it.

-Her engagement with Driver is about 50% of the story, and to be honest it works very well for helping keep some form of engaging conversation and dynamic in this movie, and she really plays the dual part well.

-You can guess Driver is the best though, and the man continues to take his rather monotone performance and bring with it, this sensational character from the grind.

-He has this astute level to him, but then loses the cool, and it works so well as he takes all the emotional moments and uses a gradient to sell the scene. Incredible performance given much of it is with non-existent creatures.

The Pace -It's a movie that moves okay for me, but I can appreciate not having the most dives into the characters given the boundaries.

-65 may not be the most engaging tale, but it certainly works towards getting to a goal and exploration and maintains it for about two thirds of the movie.

-It gives you time to deal with things, tries to give ample exploration of the shot gunned elements, and then leave you a bit on edge for much of the movie.

The Authentic Music -The score is truly grandiose like the movie's premise and world, a symphony of instruments that comes together to really bring out the moods of the scene.

-Blaring horns and drums add the forlorn and powerful shadows of the beast, while flutes, acoustic guitars, and chimes go for the more serene.

-The end credits in particular are my favorite a combination of everything I just mentioned making the picturesque credits have some ambience and get ready for the epilogue to come from this film.

Visual Design And Animation -This movie is very big on the technical prowess and involves a lot of costume work, scenery, and computers to get the job done.

-In the costume department, the Sci-Fi look is strong, fashionable blends with practical props that really do feel like something in this situation. Simplified and yet representing.

-The makeup helps big time with the injuries sustained, making them look raw, exposed, and festering like something that you would expect. It adds ambience and believability to the film indeed -As for the prehistoric beasts, I liked the design, the colors, and the evolutionary traits that they showed, alongside the savage feature in the way they moved. It's got great texture, good fluid movements of reptile behavior, and quite honestly a menacing factor to it that works.

The Cinematography -Beautiful shots of an environment with the CGI spectacle of prehistoric Earth, make this truly a lovely movie where cameras tell so much.

-The way they capture nature, give you the sense of the wide world, but then connect it to these traps, enclosures, and situations just helps capture the moment of being there.

--And then the big moments at the end truly captivate the attention of the viewer, with these expansive shots that are quite honestly amazing.

The Sound Editing -This helps really bring the experience to life for me, and how the engineers caught the effects of the world and made it add that finesse.

-The warbles of the outside creatures, the rumblings of the big beasts and the predators within, and the dynamic motion of nature are all things that really are amazing in this film that I loved watching.

-And then add the science fiction sounds of technology, the sensors, blasting, etc., and you just get this amazing experience that really is important in a movie where aesthetic is doing a lot of the lifting.

The Sense of Suspense -And at times, there is a lot of this movie that is suspenseful, and worthy of the theater experience.

-It's a dark movie, and our band of two is not invincible, where each hit has lingering consequences for the most part. That realism and edge are great in these moments, and add that terror that they might not make it at any point.

-That's the experience of this movie that is probably the best in terms of story, the fear of survival and the unknown.

DISLIKES:

The Scenes Not Needed -This is something I hate big time, including something with little points that involve stretching to metaphors.

-65 has about four of these moments, that do little to progress the story, add some unneeded times, and just have no big repercussions compared to other things.

-One of these involves unnecessary seeing of animal cruelty, which I get, in a movie for survival you can see, but serves no point when I got that with three other scenes that had purpose.

-These moments do little for me and are more annoying/insulting than anything.

The Direction Of This Communication Boundary -There is a part of this concept where the two unable to understand each other work for several premises and the plot component -But it does become annoying for me, when there is this odd banter and drawn out drama that goes practically nowhere. And by the end, the two of them are in sync and go a tad fast in how quickly they understand each other. So... it's both a love and a loss in my book that gets offset by the fact that there is sentimental components to things.

The Cheese Factor At Times -Sentimental moments can be heartwarming, but there is also a tad cheese factor that feels like Full House to me.

-Some monologues that feel a tad rehearsed, and the repetition does not approach AE levels, but still get a touch annoying given the number of times they repeat.

-There are some conveniences as well that are a tad cheesy and this sort of cataclysmic bad luck becomes more humorous than anything else to the point of again waiting for this to be over.

Animation A Tad Fake Looking -Design check, movement check, and the sounds check, but... the reliance on CGI still holds a level that has that fakeness to it.

-It's not a bad fakeness, but there is just that look and polish that makes it stand out, that robots and props, and DreamWorks did better with back in the day.

-But overall, it's not that bad, but still a tad out of the works that computers just cannot get done.

The Plot -This is the weakness that seems to be dividing fans of the movie and I'm here to sort of give the ups, but what I disliked.

-The plus side is that the movie's plot is realistic, a trial of human spirit, and poetic with the way it's handling this concept. It serves to do the job of symbolic human spirit, and a primal instinct of the world. That's the cool part.

-It just doesn't sell the other parts well, and the limited dialog, the pointless shots, and the lack of engagement fully with all the beasts makes the story inconsistent and rather simplistic and cliché.

-Then throw in these elements haphazardly thrown in, a looming threat you think will follow, but then kind of does and then doesn't. It's a tad messy and boring, which then sort of takes away from the excitement.

The Pace of the Ending -And the plot really stands out in its limitations for me near the end, where suddenly things get very hasty and rushed.

-A timeline suddenly gets established, there is hasty wrap ups of things settled, and the suspense has to be randomly adding more things to get in the way.

-Sure, there is some excitement to help, but... it doesn't mean it's the strongest motivation and devices to help make the story stand out and kind of got hokey with it as well.

-Thus, the ending shows some poor planning and the potential to make a few scenes get cut so we could have made a better ending and maybe add a little more cohesiveness.

The VERDICT: What this movie does right is get the feel, look and sounds of the Earth in the prehistoric state and all the aspects of surviving in the foreboding world it was. It utilizes technology to bring the extinct beings back into the world and how savage the world was back then, while having some good actors to interact with the fake environment. That is the brilliant part of how much this movie is a theater movie for the tech standards, or at least a good home theater if possible to make the most of it. Sadly, for me, the story is cool from the one aspect of survival, but from the other simplistic, cliché, and a tad overboard with the amount of bad luck these two seem to have. Certainly the first two-thirds keep this relationship engaging, but that last act, though having some bite, really just fails to keep the pace or maximize the potential of the movie. Beautiful and symbolic as it is, it just lacks the finesse it needed, and only the emotional side prove dominant for me in this film to get past the bloated and overdramatic finish. Throw in the unnecessary scenes that did little for me and again, this movie just needs some cleanup to be the masterpiece people want it to be. Thus, putting all this in, here are my scores

Action/Adventure/Drama: 7.0-7.5 Movie Overall: 6.0-6.5.

review_title: From the writers of A Quiet Place...

review_detailed_main: It's an okay movie, only watchable in a theatre or a big screen because that's where it can be enjoyed best I think. The actors did thier job well acting was good especially by Adam Driver he fits the role really well, I think there was a lot of unexplored potential the story was bland and not creative couldn't make the connection with the characters that I really wanted to some weird cuts they didn't show some parts i feel like they could've done well with overall I'll recommend to watch it if you have nothing better to watch in a theatre the visuals were pretty good I think a good job was done there but overall it was bland a few good jump scares.

review_title: They had an idea and that's it.

review_detailed_main: It seems many reviewers didn't like this film. I have to disagree. It kept my interest throughout which is really saying something for a Netflix movie. Adam Driver is lovely and always enjoyable. The girl was fine. This movie has dinosaurs which I wasnt expecting since I knew nothing about it before I saw it. I always prefer to go into a movie cold with no preconceived notions from the trailer or whatever. Yes the science was mostly preposterous of course but so what. This is like a survival movie and a good story. The effects were good. It's the kind of film where you have to suspend any skepticism and enjoy it for what it is. I give it a 7/10. Watched on Netflix.

review_title: At least there were nice colors

review_detailed_main:
Our family was the target audience so we enjoyed this movie. Our kids love anything with dinosaurs and we all love sci-fi thrillers. The premise of the movie is great and in theory the story was not bad. The issue with it is it seems like this was based on an outline of what the movie was supposed to be, but it never got fully fleshed out. The kids loved the dinosaurs but as dinosaur fans they did not appreciate that the the dinosaurs were all essentially monsters and the bad guys. Of course that's what they are but JP/JW fans are going to root for the dinosaurs.

Adam Driver runs like Harrison Ford, which I realized is kind of funny. :-)

The basic premise for this surprisingly cheap looking production is Adam Driver vs. Dinosaurs. That's all you're gonna be getting, and some indifferent CGI effects that make this a throwback to that appalling BBC pretend drama WALKING WITH DINOSAURS don't help much either. The story sees Driver's spaceman crash landing on Earth some 65 million years ago, where he finds his ship smashed, a young girl for company, and lots of hungry beasties trying to get their fill of him. There's a lot of action, inevitably, but none of it particularly impresses. I don't mind Driver as an actor but he can do little with his underwritten role here.

Saw it today. Wow amazing acting, cinematography, cgi/special effects, music and sound design was off the charts. The dinosaurs most of all were awesome and loved every minute of this film. I guarantee the critics or rotten tomatoes will bash it but if your a true dinosaur fan or a true sci-fi fan this won't bother you and you know what your getting out of this film. I was very shocked at the on going heart-felt moments of Adam driver in the dad role! (Pedro pascal should be jealous!) The movie has great dinosaur designs I don't understand the knock on them, and they are definitely in the movie for more than 5 minutes!! Haha people are just trying to hate and exaggerate the hate they had I guess. Go watch this popcorn flick the right way. In a theatre!!!

review_title: I think it was nice, but...
review_detailed_main: Good story line, could've been improved to merge with our current earth timeline as a more meaningful friction, but it didn't. Some attempts and symbolism were made to draw the parallels, like for example when the girl drew some doodles in the cave wall to signify her mom and dad (family), and how earth developed cities and buildings in the ending time lapse, but they skipped the gradual progression towards it. In most of the movie tries to make you familiar with the suppose environment of Mesozoic Era, and a objective to reach from point A (Crash Site) to point B (Escape Site), which could've been a great video game plot idea, like the video game BulletStorm.

I knew to keep my expectations low for this film but damn was that bad.

I really wanted this to be good or at least ok. The trailer looked decent but it was just false advertising.

The story has no structure as we just go from scene to scene with no thought in how things were put together. The editing was atrocious, the cinematography was terrible, and the lighting was trash. Though to be honest that could be due to the projector in the auditorium I was in.

Poor writing, terrible dialogue, bad cgi, and the performances were just ok. Not even Adam Driver could have saved this film.

A surprising amount of people showed up for tonight's showing but I'm sure they are also wishing they did not watch this atrocity.

I highly recommend skipping out on this film and if you are an Adam Driver fan and you somehow for some reason must watch this then wait to rent it or when it undoubtedly hits a streaming service.

Well I'd say 65 ruined my night but I still have Scream VI coming up in my double feature so here's hoping Scream can save the night.

IMDb: 1/10 Letterboxd: 1/5

Watched in Theaters.

review_title: Shut your brain off and enjoy.
review_detailed_main: Alright not a masterpiece at all, and it couldn't be more far fetched. But the effects were very well done and i liked the concept. It turned out to be an extremely entertaining guilty pleasure. It was decent for what it was! A nice change from jurassic world movies and there is some heart to it. Don't listen to the negative reviews. Unless your expecting something master class then yes, listen to the negative reviews. But, if you need a brain shut off once in a while, and want to enjoy some mindless entertainment then watch it. Especially if you dig dinosaurs. (pun intended) The acting was good. The action great. Check it out.

review_title: Dreadful, terrible, dreadful and even more terrible and back to dreadful

review_detailed_main: With all the movies out there at this time, this movie was unexpected. The story line is something unexpected. I'm not a snob of movies where I expect a moral story. This was just simply a enjoyable movie, with action scenes, good visual effects, characters that you could want to accomplish what they set out to do, to live to fight another day. The ending, well I like a happy ending and this didn't disappoint. My husband and I both enjoyed it and I'd have to say it deserves at least a 6 if not a 7. I'm not sure why I have to post a 600 word review. I can say it in less words, I enjoyed the movie and would recommend it to everyone to watch !

review_title: Not bad, but not a classic.
review_detailed_main:
It's an easy watch and you will probably only do so once. Yes it's got it's faults, but most films do.

It's not Jurassic Park or Star Wars so I don't understand why people use it as a comparison?

I get it has dinosaur's and spaceships but that's it.... Oh and Adam Driver.

Would I go to the cinema to watch it? No.

Would I watch it at home? Yes.

Storyline has been used in similar films previously, but that can be said about most films, tv shows or music these days.

Don't expect to be blown away, just sit and watch it, two enjoyable actors, some decent CGI and a couple of T-Rex chasing the hero around.

review_title: An Embarrassment To Have The Raimi and Driver Names On This
Not a Dinosaur Fan - I'm an Action Film Fan
review_detailed_main:
I've saw Jurassic Park once and that was back when it first came out. I was not a fan and do not care for dinosaur movies. I am reviewing this as someone who loves action films and is also an Adam Driver fan. He is very good in this action film and I hope there will be more for him in this genre. The reluctant hero character suits him.

He is one of the best overall actors and portrayed the grieving father and hopelessness of this situation so well. Ariana Greenblatt was a believable terrified little girl. I'm not familiar with her earlier works but she is a great actress.

I really liked this movie. For a two person main cast and 90 minutes it was all the action it could be. The acting were amazing and the story line interesting. Sad that so many people were expecting a Jurassic Park type and rating it so low based on them not getting what they were expecting and not giving the movie the chance it deserves. I'll be watching it again.

review_title: Such a great premise completely butchered
review_detailed_main:
Premise reads like it was written for me: sci fi, space, dinosaurs. Then add Adam Driver. Everything to make an amazing movie. But too formulaic, too predictable, a classic linear adventure story.

The dinosaurs, while the graphics are certainly good, are not looking line dinosaurs. Dinosaurs are cook as they are, why try to change that (jurassic world movies, this one).

In the beginning the sci fi background kept me pulled in, but towards the second half of the movie that got completely lost. Awful writing. Ending is the worst part of the movie, could have easily been from a crappy B movie. If you're bored and got nothing else to watch, give it a try. Otherwise, please don't even bother.

I don't know why so many negative reviews.

This is one is pretty decent to watch.

I enjoyed it from start to end.

Acting is good , there has been similar story lines but this is different , the journey to survive after ship wreck keeps you on toes and all the twist and turns are very good.

You can relate to both characters and ups and downs that follows.

I haven't seen a good survival movie as this in quite some times.

Maybe it's all the nonsense super hero movies that eating our brains slowly.

Watch it and rate it if you can , we need more these kind of movies rather than brainless super hero movies coming out.

I enjoyed the movie. I finally watched the long awaited movie.

My favorite things are that Adam Driver is acting in the lead role and maybe the animation of the dinosaurs.

65 is good with the story and the actors. Adam Driver is playing the character Mills and Ariana Greenblatt the character Koa. So Millses ship crashes on an unkown planet. There is only one person who survived (Koa) including Mills. So Mills's and Koa's mission is to get to the ship so they can leave the planet. During the travel they see dinosaurs but Mills has a gun so they fight for their lives.

Anyways the movie is good and it's kind of fun.

I was really looking forward to a SF mixed with dinosaurs but i was disappointed. The lines and dialogues are not cohesive and sound dry, spaceship is ridiculous, ships computer sounds ridiculous, the characters continuously make the wrong choices and what could have been great moments is not explored. The acting is not bad but the screenplay and directing is just very poor. The whole thing just feels rushed and very predictable, the end scene and images are just ridiculous.when the lights came on in the theatre I saw everybody looking at each- other with the same look in their eyes "what was this ? "

review_title: Critics hate this movie, but I really enjoyed it!
review_detailed_main:
IN A NUTSHELL: The dramatic story is about an astronaut who crash-lands on a mysterious planet, only to discover he's not alone.

The film is both written and directed by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods, who also worked together on the film Haunt. The movie was shot in only 40 days! Another thing that's unusual about this movie is that it only had one press screening before its release, less than 24 hours before it was released worldwide!

THINGS I LIKED: I adore Adam Driver. He'll win an Oscar someday. I really wanted him to win for his performance in the film Marriage Story, but Joaquin Phoenix definitely deserved the Oscar for what he accomplished in the movie Joker. Did you know Adam Driver was a Marine? He gets to use some of his weapons training in this movie.

Ariana Greenblatt is such a little treasure and totally adorable. I think I first saw her in Love and Monsters, a movie I really enjoyed and highly recommend for its creativity and humor. She is a great, young actress with a very bright future in Hollywood.

Some of the filming took place in the Kisatchie National Forest in Louisiana.

Koa is a Hawaiian word used in the movie that means "warrior." There are moments when you feel like you're watching another Jurassic Park movie.

The title gets its name from the fact that we get to see the earth 65 million years ago.

The emotional heft is a bit cliched, yet still very effective, reminding us that family is everything.

Very good and believable special effects and CGI.

In a year slated to be filled with sequels and franchise additions, the fact that this movie is original is one of its strengths.

Critics hate this movie, but I really enjoyed it!

An interesting element of the film is that the two leads don't speak the same language and have to figure out how to communicate in other ways.

THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE: The plot is pretty simple, but that doesn't make it a bad movie.

Not enough dinosaur moments. A few of the dino scenes look like they're straight out of Jurassic Park like when we see T-rex's face slowly emerge from a dramatic waterfall.

I would like to have seen more of Chloe Coleman in the film. She's another young starlet who is fantastic. I loved her in My Spy.

Sometimes, it's hard to see what's happening in the dark, cave scenes. They'll be hard to see on small devices if you stream the movie.

TIPS FOR PARENTS: We see some blood and gore.

Some dinosaurs die brutal, disgusting deaths.

Violence We see some dead bodies.

Kids will be excited to see some dinosaurs!

There are some scary, intense moments that could frighten young children.

People in perilous situations.

Lots of destruction.

!

review_title: There is nothing worse than a boring movie
review_detailed_main:
For a 90 minute movie that should have passed fast, this one felt like an eternity.

Sometimes a movie is so bad it's funny and you can still enjoy it not despite but because of its flaws. However, not when the movie is boring and this one is, plain and simple. There is nothing interesting - plot is predictible, characters are flat, I don't even remember the music and the shots? Well, let's say some commercials are shot better. And they have characters with more potential, too.

I can't say I enjoyed even one minute of this disaster. And I like sci fi. I like dinosaurs. I like disasters and tragedy. But, for me to truly enjoy it? Let me care for characters. And what do I get? An orphaned girl and a grieving father who bond, which should be great, except they are so characterless it just feels like something the creators decided they needed to do more than what they cared about. It's like somebody was going over a list of what a sci fi, survival dinosaur movie should have and mashed it all together into a movie. Without any thought or reason or even an ounce of real emotion behind it.

This movie was supposed to be fun instead it was so boring it made me angry enough to write my first review ever. Great achievemnt guys!

review_title: I thought it was a lot of fun.
review_detailed_main:
I'm sure a lot of people went into this expecting Jurassic Park. What we got instead was a point A to point B adventure with dinosaurs sprinkled in. In my opinion, the Dino's weren't the highlight of the film - it was more so the performances of Driver and Greenblatt and how the relationship between their characters grew. The scares were effective, a lot of the tension was well executed, and I loved how out of the box it all felt. Some interesting uses of tech as well!

Is it a GREAT film? No - it's got its share of problems and I was hoping for some more Dino variety. But otherwise I definitely plan on buying this on Blu-ray!

review_title: Very good for what it is
review_detailed_main: Actually very good, I'm a sucker for sci-fi and dinosaurs mind you. The CGI and dinosaurs were very good. Nice laser gun with very satisfying laser gun noises to take out those dinosaurs. Very good acting. Adam Driver is pretty good, and the other actor was also good! Not much of a plot but that didn't really matter in this case. Jumped out of my skin a few times. Its also commendable that someone has made a movie that is only one and a half hours long, deserves to be seen just for that (saved me an hour and a half with which i was able to do a bit of shopping while i was in town). Overall i would say ignore those low reviews, not sure what they were expecting but exceeded my expectations.

review_title: Absolute rubbish, even the worst of Jurassic park is better than this disaster.
not much happening until dumb things happen
Can a movie rely on special effects?
review_detailed_main: Special effects on this movie were rather impressive. However, it lacked in many areas. The lack of depth in the plot was evident as only two characters were really featured. The movie relied on action and intense interactions between the characters and dangerous creatures to be entertaining, ultimately lacking any depth. The lore was inconsistent and almost laughable at times, as random items seemed to appear when needed and the characters defied the laws of physics multiple times. I am a believer in the idea that movies are meant to entertain and usually shouldn't be taken too seriously, but this movie was quite hard to watch at times and lacked any real substance from a story point of view. Not the worst film ever, but I was disappointed.

review_title: We're here for Adam Driver shooting dinosaurs and bonding with a kid. Proceed.
review_detailed_main:
You can see why filmmakers and studios seem reluctant to make a good old-fashioned 90 minute action film these days.

The response to 65 was quite depressing to those of us who pine for blockbusters to go back to being that length. A predictable box office disappointment, a total dearth of positive reviews. It seems that we *can* have nice things but they have to be half an hour longer than 65. At least.

Look, I'm not asking for *all* the films to be this short, that would be unreasonable. But also nice. John Wick: Chapter 4 is nearly three hours long and I can't wait to see it. The more John Wick, the better. I hope the next Mission: Impossible film is 18 decades long. But some things clearly do need to shake hands with brevity and this is one of those cases.

There are those that have questioned why it's so short. We've been so starved of films where we have time to do other things with our days before and after that we're suspicious when something like this comes along. I didn't notice any huge gaps in proceedings here. It tells us what little we need to know and gets on with it. We're here for Adam Driver shooting dinosaurs and bonding with a kid. Proceed.

It stops off at the moments of expected trauma and character interactions, that much was to be expected. But there are plenty of moments of solid action and danger, nothing at all mindblowing but absolutely enough to make for a good time. Then it just ends and that's the end of that. Thank you very much, that's exactly what I left the flat for. And thank you Adam for gracing something that you're quite clearly too good for, much appreciated.

I'm an Adam Driver fan, but even he can't save this movie. There is nothing really wrong with it, but there's nothing really right with it either. It just takes every basic trope from every other dinosaur and sci-fi movie and uses them at their most basic effect.

Driver is Mills, an astronaut from a distant planet who agrees on a two year mission to get the funds to save his dying daughter. While in cryogenic sleep, his spacecraft is hit by asteroids and he wakes up just in time to crash land the craft. Everyone else on board dies so he strikes out on his own to find two of escape pods that his onboard computer tells him are still functioning. Along the way, he discovers the sleep pod of another passenger, a young girl named Koa (Ariana Greenblatt) who speaks a different language so they have to communicate as best they can.

There are dinosaurs, swamps, and quicksand to fend off. None of this is original and nothing really interesting happens. They just fight off various creatures and go from one danger to another. There is a twist ending that the writers seem to hope no one remembers a certain 1968 movie about astronauts crash landing on a planet.

The special effects are good, but nothing you haven't seen elsewhere.

Similar in vibe and quality to Prey. More successful than the two Jurassic World sequels, perhaps on par with the first Jurassic World film, without the baggage. Adam Driver make a very credible action star; he has the right physicality and he used to be in the marines and it shows. I'd happily watch him in more action roles, though I'm equally content to see him in prestige pictures and weird indies for the rest of his days. I really can't tell why this has been judged so harshly. I don't buy into defending a crap film on the grounds that *it's just a bit of fun*, this is a solid effort. Does what it says on the tin.

The plot is bland and formulaic, the characters are dull and there isn't enough of a narrative to keep you interested. Focusing on the action rather than isolation or character growth could have worked, but the snappy editing makes for a disjointed and unoriginal journey. The dinosaurs are menacing and look great and there's a few jumpy moments due to the sounds and special effects, but it's nothing special. The CGI at the end of the movie was pretty poor and the relationship between the leads was annoying more than endearing.

Overall, I would score 65 as a three out of ten. Should have stayed extinct.

review_title: Don't go into it expecting Jurassic Park and you'll be fine
review_detailed_main:
I love dinosaur movies, but I don't expect a whole lot from them, and this one was no exception. The things I really liked about the movie: it had both spaceships and dinosaurs, a character-driven storyline, and a lack of forced funny moments.

Things I did not like: I question why a spaceship doesn't have shields to protect itself from an asteroid belt, sometimes the movie is too serious.

What surprised me: I didn't expect the movie to not really be about the dinosaurs. I went in expecting an escape from man-eating monsters, but the movie is really about two survivors just trying to go home. The dinosaurs are auxiliary characters. They're animals, the movie treats them like animals, and they behave like animals. There aren't a lot of action sequences, because Driver is too busy being the best babysitter a girl could have while stranded on a new planet.

Having watched the trailer to this film and seeing the dinosaurs revealed there, I thought it was a bit of a missed opportunity and that it should have been a surprise to the audience as they watched the film instead of having it spoiled in the trailer.

The CGI used in the space scenes isn't great and the spaceship itself in the beginning scenes reminded me of a cheap knock off Star Wars ship. Thankfully, the CGI used for the dinosaurs is a little better, although it's hard not to compare a dinosaur film to Jurassic Park/World. The set design and location are impressive and it adds a lot to the film.

Although Adam Driver isn't the best actor in my opinion, he does a good job as the lead and plays well off of promising young actress Ariana Greenblatt who has a mostly non-verbal role.

One thing that confused me was the fact that the film is meant to be set 65 million years ago, and the main character is from another planet yet conveniently speaks American english and wears 21st century clothing.

Overall, not a bad sci-fi film, but I think it could have been more successful with a larger cast and a less predictable plot and ending.

Wow this movie is bad. The worst of Jurassic Park combined with a Hallmark Christmas special. This is next level straight to video trash.

Based off the trailer I thought it was going to be a generic run from dinosaurs type movie, and I was right, but also they squeezed in 60 minutes of crying over family photos. Every family drama troupe is here. Annoying kid is looking for a family. Annoying father misses his daughter. Man and child don't understand each other. Girl throws tantrum for no reason.

How do you even make a dinosaur movie with no suspense? This is hilarious to me. It's like someone quickly scrubbed through Jurassic Park and copied the worst parts. Thankfully this is a very short movie which also makes me believe that the producers realized they had a stinker and gave up.

review_title: Better than consensus would have you believe...
review_detailed_main:
I watch and rate a lot of movies, and I thought this was solid, as far as Sci-Fi movies go.

It's always seemed kind of odd/crazy to me that 'Jurassic Park' has had a monopoly on Dino-Movies for decades. It was nice to see another take.

The concept was pretty cool.

Of course there's some holes in the story, but that's why there's "Fi" after "Sci".

I'll never understand people who strongly criticize "unbelievable" plots. It's a movie! None of it's real!

Anyway- The acting of Driver and Greenblatt was VERY good. That little girl def has a future in Hollywood. Crazy there's only 4 ppl in entire cast, 2 for 95% of it.

Special effects were solid. Dinosaurs looked awesome.

My biggest complaint... like others, is the lack of Dino screen time. I understand not overloading it with action scenes, but they def could've shown sone more Dino "B-Roll" or something.

Other than that, I thought enjoyed it.

100% Worth the watch.

It's a shame it was a box office flop. Unfortunately that prob means we have to wait another 10/15 years before we get another big budget Dino movie. (Except for Jurassic park over and over again, of course)

65 is a strange little film that at times made me feel quite frustrated and at other times I was along for the ride.

Due to a major plot decision the movie is lacking in dialogue which I found robbed the movie of some much needed depth.

Visually the movie is pretty spectacular with some of the best looking beasties I have seen in a while so props to the visual effects team.

The story is also a little rushed like it was made for an audience with a short attention span...and perhaps it was :)

Adam Driver is effective as usual, the other key cast member also does a solid job.

Its ok but don't think about it much :)

review_title: Enjoyable. Won't blow your mind, but it doesn't need to.
review_detailed_main:
The premise had great potential, but the progress was somewhat predictable yet enjoyable.

It's not going to blow anyone's mind, but then again, does any dinosaur movie need to?

It's not made by Christopher Nolan.

Comparing it to classical like Jurassic Park isn't fair to do. 65 itself stands as a decent dino movie and it doesn't need to apologize for anything else. I'm actually thankful that it kept it simple because if something like this movie is overdone, it can become absolutely unwatchable. It's the simplicity that kept it grounded to be enjoyable.

So, turn off your brain and enjoy this year's most decent monster adventure flick.

There's the bottom rung of the ladder... and then there's this. One and a half hours of utter drivel. Adam Driver is no leading man, but I'm guessing he came cheap, same as the non-sensical script writer and the talentless director(s). There's actually so much wrong with this film it's difficult to know where to start or fathom how someone in the film industry thought junk like this was worth financing. Well I hope you lose your money because you deserve to for making the viewing public suffer through it. Like most films today I'm guessing the bulk of the budget was blown on the mediocre CGI in the hope that would pull the whole thing together. Those of you rating this garbage more that the 1 star it deserves are part of the problem. Don't encourage them!

I had not really heard anything particularly great about this 2023 sci-fi action adventure movie titled "65" from writers and directors Scott Beck and Bryan Woods. Yet, I still opted to sit down and watch it, since I hadn't already seen it, plus I also prefer to form my own opinions on a movie.

Writers Scott Beck and Bryan Woods didn't exactly revolutionize the cinema with this movie. Sure, "65" was a watchable movie for what it was, but it was also a very generic movie and a somewhat forgettable movie. If you think "Lost in Space" mixed with "Jurassic Park", then you essentially have the key formula that made up "65".

Yeah, "65" is the type of movie where you just lean back and sit along for the ride. The movie doesn't really require much participation from the audience. So just sit back, munch on the snack and watch the pretty CGI as Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt make their way through a prehistoric forest full of dinosaurs.

That was essentially all that the movie had to offer, so you're not exactly in for a cinematic experience of grand caliber when you sit down to watch "65". And thus, it is watchable for what it was, and chances are that come next week you will have forgotten all about the movie.

The movie has a really small cast ensemble. But I will say that the actors and actresses in the movie performed well enough, taking into consideration the severe limitations imposed upon them by a restrictive script.

Visually then this is where "65" shines. The CGI effects in the movie are great and look great on the screen. Truth be told, the CGI effects were mainly the reason why the movie stayed afloat.

I managed to sit through "65" and was adequately entertained. It wasn't a great movie, and chances are slim to none that I will ever return to watch it a second time.

My rating of directors Scott Beck and Bryan Woods's 2023 movie "65" lands on a six out of ten stars.

review_title: Yes, you are the only one who liked it.
review_detailed_main:
Also, a huge sci-fi fan and this was a repeat of 10 movies just cut up and pieced together with no acting. An AI driven CGI version would have been better. Definitely would have been more original and some depth of emotions involved. The attempt to create emotion is so drawn out and predictable it was boring. The movie should have ended when he was going to end it. That would have saved us all an 1hr 15ish (gotta watch the first 8-10 minutes to get there).

R2D2 should have popped out of the swamp and saved the movie, but alas no such luck and it the movie was not saved nor was my night.

Maybe, if you just watch it to figure out how many movies it copies, it might be worth it. ????

If you've watched the trailer, you've basically seen the movie.

Some poor sequences and the fact they decided to make the characters speak two different languages, and therefore unable to understand each other, left me pretty annoyed.

I just couldn't see the sense in the language disparity nor could I see benefit to the script and pace of the movie. It's like they lacked the ability to write any meaningful dialogue so elected to fill the gaps between the 'action' with some redundant attempts to communicate effectively.

There's a scene where they get attacked by a pack of some ferocious raptors/trex hybrids and instead of sensing the urgency to flee the area, the girl curls up in a ball afraid while Adam sits patiently for nighttime to fall, thus exposing them even further!!! So so stupid!

Don't get caught out by FOMO, this one is a dud that I watched with my monthly cinema pass, I'd have definitely felt cheated otherwise.

review_title: I was hoping for a great sci-fi
