review_detailed_main: I was hoping for a better movie. Adam is a great actor but this movie was just too slow. I don't usually say negative or bad things about a movie. But how did they manage to make a movie like this to slow and boring? And yes I think Another Earth was alot better. But it's hard for two actors to create a great movie. This movie has great effects and visuals. After watching this movie I thought it would have been better if the dinosaurs won. They managed to live for 200 million years without destroying the earth. If you're a sci-fi fan then this isn't the worst movie but don't expect to much. I was hoping for a better story.

review_title: Turn off your brain and have fun
review_detailed_main: I don't understand all the negative reviews for this movie. Going into it I expected to see an over the top scifi movie with dinosaurs chasing humans it delivered exactly that. People need to relearn how to suspend belief when they watch movies and just enjoy themselves. This is a fun campy movie that can distract you from whatever is going on in life and thats exactly what you need sometimes not some big elaborate plot. Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt are both great in this and I enjoyed watching Driver use his Marine training in this film. If you're a fan of monster films this is definitely something you should give a shot and ignore the negativity towards it.

review_title: Really? Cheap nonsense from someone's comic book? Again!

review_detailed_main: There are no twists in the plot the movie just follows a straight line not sure why this plot needs to be a movie not sure if it is a drama or scifi or thriller or documentary or action movie, you already know everything what's going to happen. Otherwise Acting, BGM and thrilling scenes are good. If you are a Adam Driver fan u can enjoy seeing him in every scene. Science behind the movie was not well defined, could have explained more about the space travel and the science behind why they look exactly like humans. There is some father daughter sentiment scenes which feels just ok. The 2010 predators was similar but was much more interesting than this.

I am a victim of them trailers... i watched it for this movie and i thought to myself, wow, Adam Driver, dinosaurs, futuristic tech, what could go wrong? Everything. It seems that their marketing was way better and i fell for it like a fool. But no problem, i'll get better at spotting them scams.

I mean Adam Driver was good, but the script was boring and dumb.

I am all for mid-budget movies, i want to encourage the studios on this path, but that doesn't mean that the script and the story has to be so lame.

I also like slow paced movies, but again, that doesn't mean that the story has to be peppered with random cringe interactions. Like the time they stopped to help the little baby dinosaur from the puddle only to end up being eaten but the little predator ones.

I mean really? You're on a strange planet full of big game hunters and instead of rushing to your ship, you make these random misjudgments?

review_title: A nice twist to dinosaur flicks.
review_detailed_main: I don't understand all the negative reviews here. Maybe these viewers missed the movie because their eyes were shut during the suspenseful parts of the movie. And there were exciting and suspenseful moments throughout the flick. There were nice special effects. The dinosaurs were realistic. What I liked about 65 was that it got right into the plot of the film and didn't waste a lot of time. The film is short, about an hour and a half. No wasteful dialog, just 2 people trying to find an escape from an alien planet that's inhabited by creatures they have never experienced before. Just watch the movie and don't pay attention to the low reviews.

review_title: Dino sci fi action thriller is entertaining but flat.
review_detailed_main:
3.5 out of 5 stars.

65 is a pretty fair sci fi action thriller film that has a promising thrill ride concept but falls flat with its characters. And story. It is no Jurassic Park films which it really tries to be. About Mills (Adam Driver) a pilot who crashes on earth which happens to be 65 million years ago when dinosaurs roam the planet. Promising concept. The story is thin. It tries to have Mills and a young girl try to search for a rescue pod. The characters are flat which we learn a little about Mills that on his estranged planet he has a daughter that is sick.

The action sequences are pretty cool. The visual effects are okay and could be worse. The script is thin with its story and characters. Which provides a brief amount of entertainment. But falls flat every where else.

review_title: I watched this on a plane and it made the flight feel even longer
Only fools would consider comparing this to previous films about Dinosaurs.
review_detailed_main:
Ummmm it's confusing to see anyone drawing comparisons to Jurassic park and rewarding this film because it's better than previous releases from that trashy franchise. They don't own dinosaurs and it's not a dinosaur film contest entry so... that's dumb.

Whats more disturbing is the whole plot line and point of this film, the premise is lame and it doesn't seem to build into anything better.

There's really nothing more to say, a bad idea like this should never have got a green light. I watched this with low expectations but that usually means I get entertained, not this time.

It's sci fi for dummies, no real edge to it. More of an action film than a sci fi mind bender.

If you hear it's boring that would be an accurate way to describe what I saw.

Went to see this film, with my twelve year old son. We both enjoyed it. Whilst no surprises, this was still entertaining with some good moments thrown in. Good acting by both of the lead characters. Won't live long in the memory, but it is still decent enough to watch. Much better than the last three jurassic films put together! Special effects are decent. Story is pretty basic but that is fine, as it doesn't need to be complex. Kids younger than eight may find it too scary but definitely ten upwards will be fine. Harmless family entertainment. A reasonable way to spend a Saturday afternoon at the cinema.

review_title: I take comfort in not having to pay for this joke
Adam Driver and a ray gun vs a bunch of dinosaurs
Days of our lives with Dinosaurs

review_detailed_main: Ok, maybe it's not breaking any new ground, and maybe it could have done with a bit more character development and world building. But if you just go into it with the decision to just enjoy a good fun time with space, dinosaurs and thrills, then you can't go wrong. I felt that it was refreshing because there was no "universe" that it was a part of, with no expectation, or pressure, to build on, and set up a larger world around it. Just a great idea, simply, but well executed. The music was also an absolute highlight. With so many films feeling so generic when it comes to the music, this was a real treat. You can't go wrong with a good bit of Danny Elfman. I absolutely loved it! The only thing I really wanted was for it to be longer and have more dinosaur set pieces.

review_title: Don't Believe the Bad Ratings - This is a good movie!
review_detailed_main: First of all, Adam Driver - need, I say more? It doesn't really matter what he's in, he's a phenomenal actor, highly underrated in my opinion. I love anything sci-fi, and this one is pretty well done. It's a good story, and has everything one would want in an entertaining film. Crazy events, things you would expect to see in the science-fiction film, great special effects, characters you care about, and, of course, once again, Adam driver! It's an entertaining sci-fi film, very well told story, and yeah it's not exactly "Jurassic Park," but with years of that franchise, this Dino film won't be unique but its still really good!

After a little while I realized this felt more like it was targeting kids, but added some blood and guts for the adults. Had so many of the traditional movie stuff. I think to many movies today rely on special effects to tell a story. The only thing it lack was the family pet. I figured along the way they would hook up with some adoring creature. Today there seems to be a real lack of quality movie making anymore. I mean even the title of the movie is weak 65? Not sure how much it cost them to make it but at least they saved of casting. Most of the movie felt awkward and never really believed any of it.

review_title: Take it for what it is and leave happy
review_detailed_main:
If you are expecting a genius movie with plot twists and phenomenal acting and revolutionary messages - you will be leaving very disappointed

BUT if you go in knowing what you are going to get , wanting to be entertained and looking past some obvious flaws ? I think you can be pleasantly surprised.

It kept your arm hairs up ( again if you let it ), the chemistry was passable between the two characters , they both did great with what they were given and the premise was honestly a pretty cool idea . I found myself genuinely into it and rooting for them and jumping at the appropriate moments - life changing ? No . Worth the 90 min ? For sure - but have realistic expectations .

If you like the Jurassic park films expecialy Jurassic 3 you will like this ,action scenes and effects top draw but story average definitely a cinema movie will lose a lot on smaller screen it's not bad but not great good acting just not best script. Would I recommend going to see it at the cinema seen a lot worse so yes it's a decent film 7/10. The 2 main stars seem to gel well together don't think they will make enough $$ to make a sequel but you never can tell with some of the rubbish to re/do , went on opening night and there were no more then 20 in the audience but bad weather didn't help ....

review_title: Worst movie I've seen in a long time
review_detailed_main: I historically like summer blockbusters and or popcorn films. In fact some of them are my favorite films just for entertainment as face value. A movie with lasers and dinosaurs checks that box and I was really excited to see this movie. It fell short and was probably one of the worst cinema experiences I've had in a long time. Even with very little expectation of this film I absolutely hated it. It took itself too seriously to hit the entertaining spoof film of Sharknado but did not execute to be the action film of the Jurassic Park series. Do yourself a favor and skip this one. This isn't even worth saving for a streaming service or a free Redbox. Watch your favorite Hollywood blockbuster over again and save yourself the time.... In fact put on cowboys and aliens and check the same boxes without the horrible movie.

review_title: 65's Big Heart Redeems Its Handful of Plot Holes
review_detailed_main:
One-sentence summary: After crash-landing an exploratory mission on earth 65 million years ago, Mills and Koa must traverse a dinosaur-infested landscape to get to their escape vessel.

The directing team of Beck and Woods have been on my radar ever since the release of their 2019 horror movie, Haunt. While I won't put 65 quite on that film's level, I was again impressed by their creativity and ambition. As preposterous as the story was, it succeeded in creating entertaining situations and earnest relationships. Adam Driver brought depth to the leading role, and both of the child actors understood the material and were up to the task. I'm not sure there was anything more that could've been done given the limitations of their script. Regardless, the directors have repeatedly proven their ability to build suspense, and I'm intrigued to see what project they choose to pursue next.

review_title: Better Than The Last 2 Jurassic Movies
review_detailed_main:
Ah Dinosaurs.

The Creatures Who Used to live in this World before. Probably They Actually Were Better Than us (Humans) Lmao. OK Let's See What This Movie delivers!..So Let's Say The Expectations I had was low as It isn't a Blockbuster Movie and I must Say it Did really exceed That Low expectations.

The story is Simple And Just a Use of Plot I must Say But It's still interesting The Dinosaurs Who were shown Had Like Messy CGI But Okay I May Speak. The Action Is surely Great and The Cinematography Is Almost On The Par Perfect. THE Sound design And Music Used was decent and The later Dinosaur escape scene is Better Than I Could expect. In The end 65 Is a Different Type of Try in This Era where Dinosaur Movies are Almost Has No existence So I may Say You should Give it a Small Try.

review_title: Pretty good not as bad as I would've thought
review_detailed_main:
Adam Drivers first time using his military background skills in a movie and the main gun reminded me of the Hallowseeker in Returnal PS5 game.

I very much enjoyed Scott Becks previous film The Haunt, didn't realize that was the same director that's pretty sweet. 65 is more enjoyable than I would've thought even with 4 hours sleep was meaning to see sooner just was busy glad I got around to seeing earlier. I love the ambient music, great action sequences, Adam Driver being legendary/comforting, and love the space views! I understand the ones that bashed this there's several parts that were cheesy or poor acted otherwise I'd say the pros out way the cons. A thoroughly entertaining action/Sci-Fi the bulk of it the bonding is magnificent and the movie is pretty cool!

review_title: By far the dumbest movie this year.
review_detailed_main:
If you ask me, they should make a sequel - there's no way in hell the second part would be worst than this one. There isn't a single thing that this movie doesn't lack. I had to dive deep into the stoic roots my existence to continue watching this abomination of a cinematic effort. The only thing more ridiculous than the acting is the plot itself. Back in the day I even managed to watch "Shakespeare in love" in one take but here....here my strength has carried me all the way to the 45 min mark when I just surrender in front of the obvious reality.

Then I realized that the answer is right in front of me: 65. 6 minus 5 and you get just the right amount of stars that this movie should get. Which is one, at best.

This movie is gonna get taken for granted I'm sure, evidenced by the reviews thus far. We shouldn't take basic movies for granted.

Proof of this is "after earth" with will smith. That movie should have been a layup. But no, they fumbled big time.

65 imo didn't make that mistake. There's literally no surprise here. The previews told us what the movie was about and film experience followed thru completely on what the commercials started.

If I have any criticism it's that the director should have left something out of the promotion. There was only one surprise, but it fell kinda flat.

But that's it. Otherwise the movies pretty solid. The young actress was nice and I liked the chemistry between her and driver.

Technically I think this movie is a nice solid 6, but I scored 7 just to balance out the haters.

On the face of it, 65 had everything I could possibly want from a film.

Adam Driver - check.

Dinosaurs - check.

Futuristic action type stuff - check.

When the trailer first came out the excitement was palpable. Seeing Adam Driver skulk through the lands of a pre-dinosaur extinction, while trying to survive, led to a high level of expectation.

Unfortunately what arrived was a chaotic, messy scenario that involved a plot that was so thin, it could have been written during someone's lunch break. Driver, as usual, was very watchable, but even he struggled to save the script and a character who is reeling from his daughter apparently dying of a cough!!!

The jump scares were poorly timed and utterly predictable and by the end, the only saving grace was the short one hour, thirty minutes run time that avoided me having to complain about having wasted a whole evening watching it.

It had a lot of good things going for it. All the actors gave great performances. The plot was fine and served it's purpose to give us dinosaur filled action and ok character development. It was short and fast paced always keeping the viewer at the edge of their seat. There was a quite a bit of suspension of disbelief that weren't too bad. The movie is simplistic and has been criticized for it but it executes well and delivers everything that it should.

The dinosaur designs were mid and music was mid. The dinosaurs weren't the most realistic looking, not only in terms of special effects but also how paleontologists would predict dinosaurs to look. The pg-13 rating held back the brutality that would come along with actual dinosaurs. I think some gore would be not only great spectacle but also reinforce the movie's themes.

This movie overall is fun pulp sci-fi but I'm not sure if I would revisit it.

Acting is pretty good on this movie, that is what allows a steady flow of enjoyment and entertainment. I appreciate it being less than 100 minutes helps a lot to keep a good pace. You don't get bored or redundant.

The horror survival story mixed with a father losing his child and then putting everything he has to save another child while fighting some dinosaurs it's justified in this sci-fi situation.

I feel the whole plot is quite dumb and that's what makes "not a great movie" because acting, special effects, dino design, character design, photo... All is pretty good tbh. Any way, this one is better than the last Jurassic Park no doubt. And I may say Driver > Pratt on this genre at least.

Pretty sure this script won a screenplay contest for kindergarten wanna-be filmmakers. Each mini conflict is preceded by the question: Let's see who's stupider: the audience for continuing to watch or these boneheaded "humans" (don't get me started with the "65" concept) who make decisions more in-line with a brainless infant.

That said, some brilliant jaw sagging/grunty performances by the two actors, who (Adam Driver obviously needed a paycheck) will more than likely never want to speak of this catastrophe again.

It's criminal how much money was flushed down the toilet to make this.

If you want to go into a self-induced coma for 4 hours, I suggest a double feature with After Earth.

Btw, I should mention my dog thoroughly enjoyed it.

review_title: Why are People so Down on this Movie?
Not so bad, but not good either

review_detailed_main: Just got back from this one and it was so bad that I just walked out. Right from the very beginning when we see them on an alien planet - looking just like humans on a world that looks just like earth, wearing normal human-like clothes and human-like hair, and speaking English - I know this was going to be a stinker. The two leads had no Chemistry and at all and it felt like whoever directed this didn't have a clue how to make two likable and interesting characters interact in an entertaining the way. The plot itself is nonsense... apparently their ship can't avoid asteroids and two seconds later it's crashing into earth. Even if you're a sci-fi fan or a dinosaur fan I still recommend watching any other movie.

review_title: Heart warming rather than heart racing
review_detailed_main: Saw a review on another site which said that the problem with this movie is that it was marketed as (and so everyone expected it to be) a dinosaur movie with Adam Driver in it when actually it is an Adam Driver movie with dinosaurs in it (yes there is a difference). This movie is not about fighting dinosaurs (although that certainly happens in it) but rather it is about dealing with grief in its many different forms, trying to live another day when the outlook seems too bleak, discovering that you can start over again even when you believed otherwise, and finding hope when you thought there was none. A nice simple movie with some action, slight thrills, and heart warming girl-dad vibes. The sound and score was outstanding.

I didn't know Sony Pictures is making a prequel to After Earth. They probably should've called this one, Before Earth. The premise was a straight up carbon copy of After Earth. Shot by shot some scenes were so similar to one another. It seems like M. Night Shyamalan's fanbase is quite strong.

Jokes aside, what happened to Scott Beck and Bryan Woods? Their writing was stellar in A Quiet Place and Haunt (2019). But in here it was atrocious and deeply flawed beyond repair. One of the most horrendous writing with subpar dialogues devoid of any depth. I hope this movie taught Beck and Woods what to do and don't when it comes to direction. Because I love their work in Haunt and I'm hoping a sequel is in the horizon.

It's not just a bad movie, it's way worse. A horrible, below amateur level direction and the preposterous editing that looks like it's done by a preschooler. A stupid and unbelievable plot that only works under visionary filmmakers. Forced "fun" moments that was one of the huge problems with this movie and probably the main reason it's bombed.

Adam Driver's career worst performance. His monotone performance was hard to watch. None of the other actors (there was only 4 people total in this movie) actually tried to perform well as they hired to do. Chloe Coleman has a bright future ahead of her, she just needed a new acting coach.

The only decent thing in this movie is that they didn't wasted all that $45 million (original budget was $91 million, the final cost of the film was $45 million after tax rebates). This movie was sure looked expensive but the VFX was sometimes noticeably poorly done.

I knew I was right for not spending my money by going to the cinema on this one. It's not a terrible movie, but it really does not payoff the cinema ticket. Adam Driver really took a beating on this one, he is constantly crashing, bumping, hitting something or being bitten by a creature. The little girl is ok-ish, but somehow I did not get any chemistry between the two characters. The action sequences are fine, graphics are fine, dinosaurs are literally taken from Jurassic Park :) The one gripe I have is that for an alien civilization, the tech, clothing, medicine ALL is 1-1 to earth in 2023. Makes the whole premise a bit unrealistic.

All in all, a mediocre movie, good for a lazy Saturday at-home, where you can watch the movie for free. Don't spend any money on this.

If you have absolutely nothing to do, no where to go and need to kill some time then go see this movie. Because that's should be the only reason. Bad plot, terrible acting and just a total waste of time and money.

The plot could of had potential but they missed the boat, well spaceship. This lacks the basic fundamentals of movie making. Cheesy scare scenes, the kid speaks Klingon and he has a daughter but treats kid like a dog at first. If you need to be entertained for a couple of hours or need the TV on for a nap, this is a great opportunity to snooze while the kids fight over the names of what is supposed to be dinosaurs.

🤦

review_title: Better than people are giving it credit for
review_detailed_main: It's not a perfect movie but it deserves far higher than the average rating it's received. Due to the budget it had I understand why it wasn't, but I wish the movie would have been longer and explored more dinosaurs and dangerous situations. However I thought they did well with what they had. The story is minimalistic but what is there is well done. The acting was good and there was no political agenda. Some scenes were predictable but still didn't detract from the enjoyment of the film. Overall I thought it was an enjoyable film with satisfying action and chase scenes. It's not something you have to think too hard about just sit back and watch dinosaurs get blasted!

review_title: Fun but formulaic dino-romp with as many plot holes as teeth.
Graphics were good, story was non existent
review_detailed_main: It's like they thought "space and dinosaurs...this is such a badass combo the movie basically writes itself!" then forgot to write an actual plot or develop the characters in any meaningful way. It would make a sweet video game, but as a movie it made me roll my eyes every time he overcame an obstacle and another one just like it came around the corner and I couldn't care less if he lived or died. It was aesthetically pleasing but it played out like it was written by a 6 year old. There was no theoretical grasp on how to build and release tension. The movie could have ended halfway through and I would have left feeling the same level of satisfaction as I did in the end, except I would've had 45 minutes of my night back. Don't waste your time on this unless you are playing it as background noise while you hangout with friends.

review_title: A Dull and Disappointing Dinosaur Disaster
review_detailed_main:
Adam Driver stars as a man who wakes up on a spaceship with no memory of who he is or where he is going. He soon discovers that he is not alone, as he is hunted by vicious dinosaurs that have somehow escaped from a cargo hold. The movie tries to be a thrilling sci-fi survival story, but it fails on almost every level.

The movie also suffers from poor production values and mediocre visual effects. The spaceship looks like a generic sci-fi set with nothing distinctive or memorable. The dinosaurs are poorly rendered and look fake and cartoonish. The movie does not create any sense of tension or suspense, as the audience can easily predict what will happen next.

The movie is a disappointment for fans of Adam Driver, who deserves better material than this. He tries his best to carry the movie with his acting skills, but he cannot overcome the weak script and direction. He has no one to play off of except for some unconvincing CGI creatures.

The movie is a waste of time and money for anyone looking for a good sci-fi adventure or a thrilling dinosaur flick. It is not hall-of-fame bad, just dumb and dull.

review_title: It could have been so much better....
review_detailed_main:
I guess this is the result when you spend 45 Million on CGI and 10 dollars on the script writer.

A lot just didnt make any sense in the story line. Adam Driver delivers a decent performance, otherwise it would have been one star less.

Altogether i found myself looking at the clock a lot. I just couldnt loose myself in the film and that is the sign that it wasnt good.

The other stars I give for the CGI and the sound.

Why not have a more interesting plot - like this: Part 1: An expedition to another planet i.e. Pre earth, the pilot in search for a healing plant for his daughters sickness has to fight dinosaurs. He is able to send the plant off into orbit, but cant escape the asteroid impact. For years he can survive eating dinosaurs (they taste like chicken...yumyum) and small mammals. He builts a hut and waits for the rescue team, but nobody ever finds him.

Part 2: About 150.000 years BC an expedition consisting of the last survivors from the same planet is looking for a new home. They have to fight the local fauna and neanderthals. Eventually they seed the homo sapiens line.

Part 3: Forward to our time. 2 different archaeologists - one discovering the remains of Driver and his tools and the other discovering the remains of the people from part 2 - are putting the puzzle pieces together. They discover that the remains are consisting of the same DNA.

There you go and i dont even want 10 dollars for it 😂

review_title: Jurassic Park meets A Quiet Place
Tricked itself with an on paper interesting idea
review_detailed_main:
This film thought it was good, but the end result wasn't.

On paper the 'what if someone was on earth when the asteroid hit and wiped out the dinosaurs" seemed like a winner, until they made a shortish film about it and kinda just left it at that.

There really wasn't much more to the movie than that short idea, and, because they don't rate the audience intelligence for much, at the 17 minute mark they specifically say "it's 65 million years ago and this is planet earth" in bold letters on the screen, just incase you thought it was some other alien world and modern or future times and you missed the premise signaled by the trailer and the movie title.

It starts off on a mysterious 'other' civilised world called 'Somaris' where they've got a nice multiracial couple who are absolutely identical to modern day humans right down to the hair styles, eyebrows and teeth and have knitted tops with sewn sleeves , and form fitting t-shirts (just like at GAP),- they didn't even try to imagine people different from upper middle class 2020 Americans even though they clearly state in the opening it's a foreign world, then they outline that they've got a sick daughter and health insurance problem, and he has to work to pay off her medical bills, ......

Then he's doing a 2 year space mission, at sub light speed apparently, cos an asteroid can hit the ship and not destroy it, and it's earth, so did these people even watch a youtube video on space travel before they cobbled this mess together? He's the pilot and he's sleeping on a bunk bed with a nice pillow, traveling slower than light speed but close to earth (the nearest system Proxima Centuri is 4.2 light years away from earth),........ they really set the tone for this intelligence insulting film.

It was pretty much a small crew and cast 'covid period' movie which didn't have to be a bad thing but the 2 main cast characters didn't speak the same language so witty and insightful dialog was off the menu and it was left to clever plot and set ups, which, never showed up.

Add in a bunch of boring cliche tropes (medical emergency fixed with a spray, giant headed dinosaurs sneaking up on them regularly, spooky cave, cliff, quicksand!!!!!!) to pad it out till the big rock hits, and then when the rock hits they didn't really do anything with it, where was the big 'splash' of earth bits that allegedly went half way to the moon? Anything except the standard fireballs raining down would have been good.

On paper an interesting idea but they didn't do anything with it except write it down a couple of times and pack it with the minimum number of tired and worn out movie tropes we've already seen in Jurassic park and other space movies.

I hope the 'continuing education' teacher who graded this gave it the d minus it deserved.

review_title: 65 delivers on the premise, with the sound and size worthy of the big screen.
review_detailed_main:
With a strong pedigreed list including Columbia Pictures as part of Sony Pictures Entertainment, BRON Creative, Beck/Woods (as the Writer/Director team here from the breakout series "A Quiet Place") AND the Sam Raimi... whew... the production quality is top notch. This includes the sound, storyline, AND get this!... the CGI too.

Here's my 2-sentence review:

"When you're at the bottom of the food chain, regardless of size, it's you, your technology, and your quick thinking; or else."

AND

"Life goes on, with or without you... be that here, there, or anywhere.

. .

*** NO SPOILERS BELOW. SAFE READING *** .

. Billed as a crash on a planet millions of years in the past, and all the challenges that situation would bring, 65 delivers on the premise.

We discover along the way that on mother's natures food chain, back then we would have certainly been at the bottom. Sprinkle in a few lighter moments, even laughable, the only thing the movie really misses on is a bit of believability. That and the important intro title screens, but more on that in a moment.

As we've all learned what to expect from the Jurassic pictures over the years, and here 65 stays true to the genre. Add in a space twist, the typical sense of urgency, and a bit of injured-hero action, we see the formula well followed without adding to many additional ingredients.

Overall Ratings: We were both in as a B- (yet I bumped mine up to a Solid B based on the mix of genres I like, and the production quality that real big screen movies should have.)

The 65 movie isn't a late night catch-it-at-home situation. Here, the sound and size is worthy of the big screen.

Hot Take: Speaking of production, don't miss the first few minutes and pay attention to the on-screen subtexts, as they completely set the stage for the background setup, and the who/what/why Adam Driver's character "Mills" is doing there out in space in the first place. Miss the titles and subtext, as you might as the titles are way to small and undersold for the importance they provide in the setup, you'll be a bit behind.

Kudos for pulling off the movie with only 4 actors in the entire film, 2 of which carry the majority. AND for the decision to integrate the in-credit scenes subtly at the beginning of end credits, not forcing us to sit and wait akin to the MCU spin on credit scenes. They were welcomed and reinforced the overall life-goes-on concept for sure.

As "65" started the weekend early on a Thursday, carve out a break for you and the family, yes family (you'll understand once you see the movie) and enjoy the show!

Come on... be fair this is definitely better than 5.7; The story line is pretty creative; graphics and cinematography is nice... You can feel the vibe of the Mesozoic Era (Age of Dinosaurs ); l mean the creepy ancient jungle full of dangers.. From the beginning till the end the tention is constantly rising. Also l can say that Adam Driver did a pretty good job.. So, l would say don't be fooled by the rating, if you like survival movies, if you enjoyed watching Jurassic park series or King Kong Skull Island, you can give it a try. Obviously, it's not a classic, there are some clichés but still nice.

review_title: Like going to the zoo when you are on safari
I lost 2 hours to this moronic Butterfly Effect misstep

review_detailed_main: I watched this despite the low scores and was pleasantly surprised. It's not going to win any awards for dialogue or originality, but it's far from a brainless action movie, either. The 'story' is a very quick setup for a survival film in which the hero and a young girl must stay alive while trying to reach their goal. There are all the usual tropes of plans that fail and plans that work, a surrogate father-daughter relationship, and a lot that is owed to Jurassic Park - as I said, it's not a completely original idea. But with no bad language to speak of and only relatively mild survival horror, this is a film you can watch with older kids who won't compare it to every other sci-fi that has gone before it. I'd probably rate it somewhere between a very solid 6 and 7, but I'm giving it 7 here because really, the low scores here are hugely unfair.

review_title: The first draft to an interesting adventure film...

review_detailed_main:
The "65" (2023) is a sci-fi movie directed and written by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods. The pilot Mills (Adam Driver) crashes on a strange planet. He is stuck on an Earth from 65 million years ago. Now, Mills and the only other survivor, Koa (Ariana Greenblatt), have to explore the unknown place full of dangerous dinosaur-like creatures, with only one chance to survive.

At its core, "65" is a complex narrative about survival on one hand. It revolves around two characters struggling to survive on a planet inhabited by dinosaur-like creatures. The tension between the characters adds somewhat depth to the plot, as their dialogue changes from not trusting each other to possibly working together. The movie cleverly introduces a plot twist in their interactions, adding depth to the narrative.

However, even though the visual storytelling is complex, the story itself sometimes feels empty and leaves the viewer wanting more, but I felt there was something specific behind this story but it was not there yet. The story would have been better if the characters' would have been better developed because this is what lacked, e.g., feelings could have been even more explored and developed.

The movie looks and sounds great, but it lacked emotional depth but later in the movie it progressed. The first 30 minutes are mostly about exploring and can be a bit boring, but they do create some kind of atmosphere.

"65" (2023) is a visually stunning sci-fi and survival story that is very interesting to watch. The most impressive thing about the movie is its score Chris Bacon and Danny Elfman, which is not only beautiful but also goes well with watching it. The soundtrack has both electronic and orchestral elements, and it really captures the tense and intriguing feeling of the film. In terms of sound effects, it has ticking sounds, deep bass effects, and different synth tones that make the sound experience just as unique as the visual one.

The CGI depiction is actually very good. It stands out because of the realistic element settings and the actual CG. The movie's environments look like they are from 65 million years ago which is the base of this story. Moreover, the CGI space creates an amazing background for the story. The film's great camera work and great transitions.

The film unfolds at its own pace, which is mostly effective, though some may find the slower moments less engaging.

In conclusion, the film "65" is not a waste of time per se. It demonstrates strong audio-visual execution and an original concept. However, it may be advantageous for the film to incorporate more character development and narrative clarity and more complexity. The film stands out in the sci-fi genre due to its skillful utilization of sound and visuals.

Greetings from Lithuania.

65 (2023) is a movie which felt that it was made in some 2001 on small budget as a TV movie. It had crazy premise that could have worked but in case of 65 - a highly predictable survivor story set, well 65 million years, it crashed and burned like asteroid that hit the earth all those years ago. If you set up aliens that visit earth on the same day as asteroid dropped, one should make those aliens feel different. And yet here they you casual movie John and girl that needs to be saved but usually saves our main hero with things like stabbing a T red with a piece of wood. Dialogs were predictable and pacing is bad - at running time just 1 h 30 min I was constantly watching at the remaining run time.

Overall, 65 is a shallow and generic and predictable TV movie made for some science fiction channel. It's boring and does not worth you precious time.

review_title: Well I enjoyed it, and so did my wife!
review_detailed_main: I suspect there are too many people expecting Disney type films and giving low reviews when a film doesn't meet their requirements. This was not, maybe, a $100m film, but it was well written, well acted, fast paced, tense and very realistic. I gave it 7 stars but maybe would have more honestly given it a 6 if the reviews I'd read had given me a more realistic view. It has a good, non-stop action vibe to it which more than compensates for the fact that the main character, Adam Driver, often doesn't appear to have a clue. There are some unlikely moves such as him telling the girl to run when a dinosaur is attacking rather than keeping her close behind him, or sequences where he appears to outrun a T-Rex. But overall it's a good film, not the best, but good enough to spend an hour and a half on.

review_title: Exciting, if a bit of a one-trick dinosaur

review_detailed_main:
Definitely better than its own reputation. Spaceships, dinosaurs and the Earth 65 million years ago - you're bound to get a good movie out of those ingredients. When you forget the stupid background of the movie, it's quite an entertaining film. Adam Driver does a great acting job again. Effects also work. When I started watching with low expectations, I was not disappointed. Vice versa.

But it is certainly true that a much better film could have been made from these ingredients. Especially if the background story would have made more sense as well. But as a functional action film, 65 really makes its case.

Adam Driver with dinosaurs, excellent idea, then why is this so boring?

I was bored watching this, this made me feel like a useless person, watching movies like this is useless, i want my time back, i don't care about the money, just give me the time back, i never complain about a movie but this is pathetic, Adam im so disappointed in you, i really wanted to enjoy this but i can't, im so sad that i didn't like an Adam movie, he is my favorite actor right now, im still a fan anyways, ok that's all, sorry if im being to critical, i was just angry but im ok now, some time has pass and i already forgot about the movie.

Should have known this movie was going to be a dud! Shame because with the high production value all they needed was a more compelling script to make this somewhat of a good movie. It was Jurassic Park, After Earth, Last of Us, and Prometheus all in one or at least that was what it was trying to be. Its strengths are definitely the visuals. As with most sci fi movies that is a huge part of the appeal of these sort of films. Unfortunately many fail to deliver a compelling script to really engage you in the story onscreen. This one is no different. The fact that two of the main characters we are forced to watch can barely understand each other makes for underwhelming conversation. So the dialogue is weak. I recommend waiting for this to stream.

review_title: This script was found in a Jurassic dung pile, wasn't it?
Appreciate a good bad movie for what it is
review_detailed_main: Seriously, all you negative people need to embrace the joy of watching a really good BAD movie. Were there plot holes? Yes, of course. But there were also humanoid astronauts fighting off dinosaurs. My biggest complaint, as a bona fide nerd, was that the dinosaurs were inaccurate (where were the feathers?!) as was the location of the impact (trying to avoid spoilers). I'm a sucker for stupid sci-fi and an old hand at suspending disbelief, so this was a fun distraction for 90 minutes. If you enjoy good bad movies, give this one a try. The graphics are good and it was entertaining enough to watch.

review_title: This is not worth your time
review_detailed_main: This movie had no direction felt meandering and yet somehow these are the positive moments. First there are some continuity issues in the storytelling in that is not a parent when certain things were happening. Second, the main driving force which sets the movie in motion seems a bit like an afterthought. We never really get to connect with the characters or The reasons behind why they feel the way they feel. Which consequently let me feeling disconnected to the outcome of their well-being. The premise to begin with it's not very compelling. If you find yourself extremely bored one day with nothing to do I would suggest you do anything else but watch this movie.

The special effects and CGI in this movie have become par for the course in all movies with dinosaurs, monster sharks, etc.

It's unfortunate that we take that creativity and tech for granted now.

As for the rest of the movie, it starts off fast but slows down somewhat in places.

The reason I give this movie a 7 star rating is because I really enjoyed Adam Driver's acting. His acting was so good that the CGI and special effects became secondary to enjoying the movie, as it should be.

There were some incongruities in the movie, but nothing that would demand your attention unless you were looking for issues to nitpick.

Ariana Greenblatt's acting was good, but like with CGI and special effects these days, child actors are expected to be better than ever, especially teens.

I like the movie enough that I bought it on Prime.

This is just the type of movie you would expect from a streaming service like Netflix or Amazon. It is what we used to see only in the Blockbuster rental store but never in a theatre (yes I just dated myself -boomer!). A "B" movie that checked a lot of boxes but you can't help but feel like something is missing. Adam Driver is good as are the two young ladies in the film. I would have to lay most of the problems with this movie at the feet of the writers and directors. Cinematography is good but the story lacks a bit of substance if not dialogue (yes I understand why but just saying). You know how it will end but they didn't flesh it out enough, and just like that the credits roll.

Ok, where do i start?

Amazing actors and performance.

Fine CGI, not perfect but surely its more than okay.

Simple story, but it would've been so much better if this movies is run-for-your-life type than fight-for-your-life against dinos.

I get it, his tools and weapons were futuristic and powerful, but still.. we're talking about dinos here, they shouldn't be killed by few shots, in the film not even combination of weapons or tactics needed to take them down. At that point i felt bad for the dinos, it feels like they just being there to get killed, didnt even give any big apex hunter type of vibe that could add more thrill to the film, with that the audience probably can feel the survival vibe which could work far more better with the story.

review_title: Good idea but a weak movie.
I enjoyed this. Why such hateful reviews?

review_detailed_main:
As we all are, I am an unashamed Driver fan. Love him in everything from Girls to Kylo Ren to Marriage Story and now 65. He is fast becoming a generational talent, but with the looming Ferrari disaster and the box office failure of this film, he needs a hit. And fast.

He is too good for this type of sci-fi silliness, and manages to lift the material from mediocre into watchable. Driver is stuck on a mysterious planet after his ship is hit by asteroids, and must find a way to escape before being eaten or incinerated.

Barbie's Ariana Greenblatt proves highly serviceable as his sidekick survivor, as the duo escape one scrape after another in a sometimes lazy Aliens/Jurassic Park/The Martian template. Mercifully, the film is a short and sharp 90 minutes. 6/10.

review_title: "In '65': A Sci-Fi Adventure Struggles to Balance Ambition and Execution"
review_detailed_main:
Title: "'65' - A Sci-Fi Dinosaur Film with Ambitious Themes Falls Short of Impact"

"'65' attempts to fuse the allure of futuristic technology with the primal thrill of dinosaurs, creating a unique cinematic experience. Unfortunately, the film, primarily driven by Adam Driver's solo performance as Mills, struggles to deliver a cohesive narrative that effectively utilizes its intriguing premise.

The movie opens with Mills crash-landing on Earth 65 million years ago, just as the asteroid approaches. While the concept promises an intense 'Prey' or 'Predator' dynamic between a lone human and dinosaurs, the storyline instead focuses on Mills' attempt to establish a human connection with his daughter and surrogate daughter, Koa.

Despite commendable cinematography, shot predominantly in the lush landscapes of Oregon and the swamps of Louisiana, the film's pacing falters, with extended periods lacking significant plot development. The limited dinosaur sightings in the initial 45 minutes may leave audiences expecting more action from a film of this genre.

Adam Driver delivers a solid performance, albeit hindered by the absence of substantial co-stars. The inclusion of a young child speaking a foreign language as his primary companion may not have fully showcased Driver's acting prowess.

While the second half introduces more dinosaur interactions, it falls short of redeeming the overall viewing experience. The film's climax, though visually striking, ventures into the realm of the absurd, leaving audiences with mixed feelings.

In conclusion, '65' struggles to balance its ambitious themes with effective storytelling. Despite moments of tension and some visually captivating scenes, the film ultimately fails to capitalize on its potential, making it less likely to warrant a rewatch. While Adam Driver's performance adds a commendable touch, the narrative choices and pacing hinder the film from achieving its intended impact."

review_title: Adam Driver, a Child Sidekick, and Dinosaurs
review_detailed_main:
There's not a lot to say about '65' that isn't revealed in the description.

The dialogue is sparse, and the physical acting isn't bad. There isn't much story beyond "We have to go from Point A to Point B to get macguffin. Oh no! Nature! Oh no! Dinosaurs! Oh no! Nature again! Oh no! More dinosaurs!" From a technical standpoint it's competently made.

The action isn't bad, but since there are only two characters and it's rated PG-13, you never get the sense that anyone is ever in real danger. The foreshadowing is obvious, there are many many holes in the plot and logic, but at the end of the day it's a film about Adam Driver running around shooting dinosaurs. Set your expectations accordingly. I'm simply grateful they didn't have the audacity to slap 'Turok: Dinosaur Hunter' on the poster.

I can't recommend '65', but if there's nothing else on and you're really bored then you may as well watch Adam Driver shoot dinosaurs in the jungle. It's probably a good background movie.

review_title: Lame, Contrived Plot With Zero Believable Dynamic Between The Leads
review_detailed_main:

Mild spoilers ahead.

It's honestly baffling why they casted a 16 year old to make the parts of a supposedly 9 year old child, she has a teenager face so it's not "adorable vulnerable child" anymore, it's weird, because he was supposed to be her father figure and viceversa, and even though Adam Driver has the age to be the father of a 16 year old (real age of the actress), he looks like he's in his 30s so it didn't add up at all. The connection they're supposed to have, nope, no chemistry, not viable in terms of the story.

The plot points that supposedly delayed their plan and made them "race even more against time" were contrived and stupid. The kid whining for nothing not one, but TWO times. Just lazy writing.

Average film.

The plot is rather weak but still understandable and acting is decent. I honestly enjoyed the movie, it's a sort of light, quick movie to watch with anyone really. The idea of the movie is nothing new but some elements are For example as mentioned above how we are the aliens, aspects like these make the movie special or would have if these elements were highlighted a bit more clearly.

How disappointing, more rawr, less blah blah. Terrible plot, terrible actors. The commercials made it seem like something like jurassic park where it be a movie dinosaur lovers would love but no, one cool scene with the trex. Low budget film with no real storyline, not enough Dino scenes. Glad I was drunk to be able to get through the disappointmentment. *Yawn*

review_title: Just give it a go. You might be pleasantly surprised

review_title: A passable and attractive Sci-fi movie with a few roles but with action enough
review_detailed_main:
65 million years ago, on the planet Somaris, pilot Mills (Adam Driver) convinces his wife Alya (Nika King) that he should take on a two-year space expedition to earn the money needed to treat their daughter Nevine's (Chloe Coleman) illness. During the journey, his spaceship, the Zoic, is hit by a mass of asteroids and later on, the astronaut crash lands on a mysterious planet only to discover he's not alone. After the catastrophic crash, pilot Mills quickly discovers he's actually stranded on an unknown planet. Now, with only one chance at rescue, Mills must make his way across an unknown terrain riddled with dangerous prehistoric creatures in an epic fight to survive. All the passengers were in a Cryogenic induced sleep and Mills was the only being awake as the pilot of the ship. Million years ago prehistoric earth had a visitor !. 65 million years ago prehistoric earth had a visitor !.

From the writers of A Quiet Place comes 65, a sci-fi thriller produced by Sam Raimi, Deborah Liebling, Zainab Azizi, Scott Beck and Bryan Woods. "65(2023)¨results to be a good mix of clichés and influences from classic science fiction and monster movies; a movie to watch with popcorn that, although it's not as exciting as it claims to be, has its moments. Here Adam Driver has to survive a trip through space and crashing with his ship in a hostile territory full of dangerous prehistoric creatures in this epic fight that mixes suspense with science fiction. Adam Driver is quite good as the hero who, after a catastrophic air-space accident in a seemingly unknown planet, has to deal with all kinds of stone-historical animals. Now he has only one chance to escape and his only companion, a girl, whom he saves but he is also saved by her. Adam Driver is accompanied by a young cast, such as Ariana Greenblatt (Barbie, Stuck in the middle) and Chloe Coleman (Dungeons and Dragons: Honor Among Thieves)

It contains colorful though dark cinematography by prestigious cameraman Salvatore Tonino and the camera often assumes a pointedly aggressive stance. As well as thrilling and suspenseful musical score by Chris Bacon and Danny Elfman . Scott Beck and Bryan Woods ( Boogeyman, The quiet place, The quiet place 2, Nightlight, 45), direct professionally this adventurous survival story survival story full of action, chills and chases througouts a dangerous and really risked environment. Rating: 6.5/10. The flick will appeal to action/adventure/terror enthusiasts, as well as adam Driver fans. It is entertaining enough despite the fact that creativity seems to have remained anchored in a distant cinematic past, either because it copies other films and mixes various cinematic genres.

A complete and absolute waste of time with not even anything worth talking about. 90 percent of the action you see in the trailer happens during the last 20 minutes of the film. The dinosaurs look awful. The action is quick and over too soon. The plot is too darn simple and very much a throw away generic by the books sort of deal. I wouldn't recommend this film to my absolute worse of my worst enemy. I almost feel sorry for the filmmaker, this is degrees within being ranked as just plain imperishable and a fart of a bad boring time. They should have hired more special effects people and just hired a no name to act.

6.5 would be honest, its not worth a 7 for me. The movie is engaging, entertaining, paced well, everything you need for an enjoyable watch. Its not the.best story and the writing does little to justify the premise, but the acting and CGI is more than good enough to still make this a very enjoyable watch. I would recommend seeing this still.

The movie isn't for dinosaur enthusiasts, space enthusiasts, its a sci-fi thriller more akin to a lovechild between Prometheus and Jurassic Park. The dinos look like monsters, act like monsters, and the movie doesn't skip an opportunity to make you jump out of your skin.

Huge movie buffs probably won't enjoy this, your average movie goer definitley will. It does what it intended to do - engage you and make you jump - its strange that they chose such a complex premise for this purpose, though.

review_title: Is a bad dinosaur film better than no dinosaur film?
review_detailed_main:
Watching this felt like someone ressurected your favourite childhood pet for 90 minutes, only for them to force you to watch them slowly strangle it.

'65' doesn't lean into being a dinosaur movie anywhere near enough considering that's how it's being marketed and realistically is the only reason anyone is going to watch it. There's more painfully unimpressive space travel, embarrassingly wooden drama and poor survivalist showcasing than there is intense dino action.

The 2008 movie 'Outlander' had better creature design, CGI and plot than this inexcusable waste of 90 minutes. Saying that. It's still better than 'Jurassic World: Dominion'...not that that's much of a compliment.

The only reason this is getting 3 stars is because I think I managed to get that many minutes of happiness watching it.

review_title: Decent Sunday Flick - Pros and Cons
review_detailed_main:
Really not that bad a watch, if you are into sci-fi, dinosaurs and what-if types of movies, you may very well enjoy it.

Pros:
Great acting by Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt.


Good CGI.






Cons:






All cons aside, this was a decent flick to turn the brain off and enjoy, and while you might not leave the theater (or streaming platform) thinking how great it was, I don't feel that it was felt as a waste of time and/or money either.

The story was very easy to follow. It's like somebody saw Jurassic Park once, kind of remembered what the dinosaurs looked like and thought "I'm going to make a film like this starring Pedro Pascal" the only issue being that they didn't manage to get Pedro Pascal.

The CGI was great, for 2005. It was giving the same vibes as King Kong on the PS2.

Honestly, I'm just trying to hit the word count now but I watched this the once and I will never watch it again. I don't want to be TOO harsh on this film because it wasn't a dumpster fire but really this film did not need to exist and watching it is a waste of time.

review_title: It's not the movie's fault if people had different expectations

review_detailed_main:
65 is a sci-fi thriller that follows a pilot (Adam Driver) who crash-lands on Earth 65 million years ago and has to survive the prehistoric dangers with a young girl (Ariana Greenblatt). The film is written and directed by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods, the writers of A Quiet Place, and produced by Sam Raimi.

The film boasts impressive visual effects and action sequences, as well as a touching bond between the two protagonists. However, the film also suffers from a lack of originality and logic, as it borrows heavily from other sci-fi and adventure films, such as Jurassic Park, Cast Away, and Avatar. The film also fails to explain how the pilot ended up on Earth in the past, or why he speaks a different language from the girl. The film is entertaining and exciting, but not very memorable or meaningful. It is a fun popcorn flick for fans of dinosaurs and Adam Driver, but not much else.

65 is a decent sci-fi thriller that delivers on spectacle, but lacks in substance.

review_title: What should've been Adam Driver's Turok is actually Adam Driver's After Earth.
review_detailed_main:
It seriously felt like there was an hour of this movie cut out. I mean I'm glad it's only 93 minutes but things move so fast that it feels inorganic. We spend so little time with Adam Driver before he's zooming off into space and we are somehow expected to care.

The fact this came from the team that wrote the Quiet Place movies makes this hurt even more. Those movies take their time and we grow to deeply empathize with the family. In 65, the first three minutes set up the whole movie.

I don't want to beat this movie up too much, it's basically what I expected from the trailer. Adam Driver is a good grunter and this movie has lots of grunting.

I wish he was on the planet alone and this could've taken a more Cast Away vibe, but what we got is what we got.

It's cheesey, it's goofy, it's thin, it's slow season at the movies. What should've been Adam Driver's Turok is actually Adam Driver's After Earth.

review_title: I wish I could have left my flight midway at 30,000 feet
review_detailed_main:
This was a free movie provided on my Jet Blue flight.

The crew likely would have not let me jump out of the plane mid flight as that option is not available.

This made my flight tough. The flight crew will not sell you enough adult beverages to numb the pain while sitting in my More Room seat waiting for this film to redeem itself.

I don't blame Jet Blue. Perhaps they should let Jet Blue Mosaic members preview the memories. This way they can reduce the amount of barf 🤢 bags needed per flight. Or, they could let us fly in a B-52 bomber so they can open bomb bay doors for those of us that can't stand the torture of a really, really bad movie.

I always yawn when I watch another of these movies that would not have happened with a working healthcare system.

But even without that flaw, ghe rest of the movie is uninspired. And it spoils even more when showing things in the least creative way. You always know whats gonna happen.

He tells he will be back soon... he will get trouble.

He makes a call "I'm alone" just to find someone. He says "we are safe" just to find trouble...

But also the directing works like patchwork. Many things are shown without having relevance. And those having an impact are solved uninspired. He is injured but magically cured in the next moment when he needs to use his gun...

It feels like a story where the two protagonists would work together kn order to overcome something. But in the end they dont. I was expecting an "Enemy Mine" with dinos but both was disappointing.

No twists. No surprises. No big moment. Forgettable acting, terrible script. From beginning to end, everything was predictable. The trailer was better than the movie.

It didn't seem like a Columbia Pictures movie, it seemed like one of those junk movies Netflix filmed over the weekend on a quest to replace quality with quantity.

I'm not a writer but I'm certain I could have rewritten the script to be more believable. The best thing I could say about this movie is that it was almost adequate.

Lucky for me, someone else paid for the movie, otherwise I'd feel ripped off by this disappointing movie.

In the beginning, it was a bit boring, but later on it was heartfelt. At the end finding out the daughter had already passed away, 3rd act was a bit more serious than most, and as the credits rolled, we see the aftermath & transition after the instinction of the dinosaurs into modern day! I did think Adam Driver's character was gonna take her in, or that a passenger did survive & it was one of the little girl's parents (mother) like a "You're not alone" type film. But I guess not, to a degree. It was a bit confusing with Homosapiens already existing & not even from Earth or whatever. But it was cool.

review_title: It lacked so much that I stopped watching
Decent movie, don't see why so much negative press!?
review_detailed_main:
Just a popcorn flick to enjoy! It's like an amalgamation of Pitch Black, Jurassic World and better parts of other sci fi movies rolled into one. Turn your brain off, enjoy a movie for what it is and relax. Too many reviews bombing half decent entertainment and killing the joy of cinema!

Cast is decent, no nonsense approach and it's entertaining!? Some good suspense, dinosaurs are fun and action scenes are great. Really liked the costume design and weapons too! Plot was direct and you know what's gonna happen before it happens making it easy to watch. I personally enjoyed the dinosaurs! It's nice to see some actual threat from prehistoric creatures and not the wishy washy crap that's been in every Jurassic Park film since the Indominus/Raptor Vs Special Forces scene in Jurassic World!

It's a movie. It's not gonna win Oscar's, but it entertains! It's a type of movie you let your mates in a group chat know that it's decent and worth watching instead of scrolling Netflix or such like for hours on end to rewatch something you've seen a million times before.

Hope whoever reads this enjoys it for what it's worth and doesn't take it too serious.

Reading other peoples' reviews make me very nervous for the human race, and just the process of thought, in general. This movie has a backdrop of science fiction, space travel, possibly time travel, and Jurassic Park action. It is all a side show. This movie is about 1 thing, and 2 people, Mills and Koa. It is a character piece/study on tragedy/survival/recovery. Both main characters are recovering from life-altering tragedies, one just doesn't know it yet. Mills knows about his and is devastated with the death of his daughter, presumably light years away, yet perseveres. Koa doesn't know the fate of her parents yet, even though she is still devastated/confused by the crash and current circumstances. She learns to trust Mills (also her only option) to help her. In the manner of strangers/distrust, it is awkward at first. But they help each other, save each other, grow to trust each other and eventually love each other as father and daughter, each filling the piece in which they have lost. The Sci-Fi and action are fun and entertaining. I also assume the nerds/Sci-Fi buffs will poke holes at the "aliens" being human and being able to breathe our atmosphere. Which is a giggle fest. In this movie, this was likely "Mankinds" first touch of earth. As you noticed, no cave men to be seen. They likely left behind a lot of cells, blood, tissue and DNA which the humans as we now know, formed out of over the millennias. It isn't meant to be a perfect action or sci-fi film, because it isn't either of those at all. It is a personal character study of two beings that were thrust into an unenviable position. They found each other, helped each other, saved each other, and became family. The action, Sci-Fi and dinosaurs were just so the average Joe would watch the film, bait, if you will. A beautiful character piece to me. I thought it was wonderful. I could watch multiple times over again. Very well made, I thought.

review_title: Solid Action film with a few hiccups
90 minutes of Adam Driver panting pathetically
review_detailed_main:
I really wanted to like this. All the ingredients were there, I love scifi, the premise looked good, decent budget, but

where do I start.

The majority of Adam Drivers dialog is panting. Hopeless panting. Desperate panting. Angry panting. A bit of heavy breathing from physical exertion. Panting out of fear. "I'm about to die" panting. "I've been rescured and I'm not dead" panting.

I think I'd had enough of his panting a quarter way through this film.

Other than the deep breathing issue, the story is slow, many events pointless, nothing kept me interested.

Given teh weakness of the story, I'm not sure less heavy breathing by Adam would have made it a good film, but it would have been a lot less bad.

The biggest twist in this movie is how a completely different human civilization to our own visited Earth 65 million years ago but they had same lamps, measured distance in kilometers, called asteroids asteroids (I mean come on) and had identical guns to ours.

Everything else is cliche, boring and predictable.

At least the original b-movies of the 50s and 60s knew they were not meant to be taken seriously. This film doesn't even bother to have fun. These people here, they thought they were making serious art.

Oh and by the way, the dinosaurs look like they came from Mars.

Overall, whoever thought of budgeting this script is clearly mental. Go watch Jurassic World instead, at least they tried to explain the story with "science". This is like an adult movie. The script is just an pretext to get to the action.

4/10 for the actors who try unjustifiably hard to give a good performance.

review_title: Underrated entertaining si-fi film with a heart
review_detailed_main:
First, please excuse me while I express a highly sarcastic observation. I'm sooooo excited by the number of 1/10 reviews this and other movies get on IMDB. With so, so many people out there with such better ideas, talent in story writing, original new world creating, character development, cgi skills, acting abilities, directorial & editing brilliance etc.... just imagine how amazing the movies we will be watching will be, when these people start making there own movies 🤗🤗🤗.

On to the movie. I really enjoyed it. Jurassic Park meets Pitch Black, with a sprinkling of Aliens. I'm not saying that it was as good as any of those movies, but to be fair, this is obviously because I've already been exposed to those movie's ideas.

I liked the movie's world tech. Cool space ship, gadgets & weapons.

I liked the dinosaurs, insects, plant life and the overall grand visual representation of the 65 million year old earth environment.

I liked Adam Driver's slightly flawed character, due to his experiences, learning to care and fight again for the girl.

I liked the girl character for lots of reasons. Not the least of which was that her character when needed, displayed the best kick arse bravery since.... well.... Kick-Ass (2010).

I liked the developing relationship between the two main protagonists. Both having suffered great loss, but learning to trust, care for, protect and fight for each other.

And to close, to the many reviewers that ridiculed the idea that Adam Driver's alien humanoid character would speak English, you're correct. That's implausible. But would it have been more enjoyable to watch if we spent the whole movie reading subtitles whilst listening to one character saying, "Be bop bop zamin shaltze herbo", and the response being "Zip doddle zap wap nolen". ??????. It's a movie device used to make the movie watchable. As the audience, we aren't supposed to think Driver's character is speaking our language.

From "Captain Obvious". 🙄.

review_title: only 65 minutes were spent developing this film.
review_detailed_main:
After a catastrophic crash on an unknown planet, pilot Mills quickly discovers he's actually stranded on Earth - 65 million years ago. Now, with only one chance at a rescue, Mills and the only other survivor, Koa, must make their way across an unknown terrain riddled with dangerous prehistoric creatures.

The idea of 65 is an intriguing concept: what would happen if an advanced civilization crashed landed on early 65 million years ago and had to survive amongst the dinosaurs? A thesis like that could only go one of two ways: a deep dive into the analysis of the superiority of technology and how it could've changed our entire trajectory as a species or an underbaked story that says let's shoot dinosaurs with plasma rifles. As cool as that sounds, the cool doesn't translate to 65, a movie about crashed space pilot Mills and fellow crash survivor Koa as they navigate the treacherous lands of the cretaceous period to reach their escape pod and rendezvous with their rescue. The front half of the movie is bland and lifeless, with Mills' motivation to raise money to help save his daughter from an unexplained (to the viewer) disease being his driving factor. Unfortunately, the five minute setup we get with Mills and his daughter doesn't do nearly enough to buy into a man desperate to get back to the people he loves (see: Interstellar for this storyline done well). For her part, Koa, wanting to reunited with her own family, joins Mills in the worst version of Lone Wolf and Cub to date. It's not until the introduction of a ticking clock that gives the movie any sort of life; the film's pace picks up considerably, ramping from lifeless to something resembling life support. Somewhere in here is a good idea attempting to escape, but any sparks of life are snuffed out by subpar writing, feeble direction, and subpar acting.

Starring Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt, the entirety of the film depends on them. With the exception of the opening scene, they're the only human characters in the movie and thusly the audience's gateway into the story. With Driver being the older, more established actor, most of the attention is owed to him and sadly here the proven talented actor is not up to task. While some credit for his weak performance must be attributed to such a trite script, Driver seems wholly uninterested in attempting his best on screen. Ariana Greenblatt is doing the best she can with her material; still only 15 years old, she has plenty of time to sharpen her skills and display her abilities in projects with more promise. The two together possess almost no chemistry; the attempts at bonding through humor fall flat and they spend almost as much time apart from one another as they do together on the screen. Had there been a more honest approach to the characters and more attention paid to the relationship between the two, the project as a whole could only have been better.

Developed by the writing/directing duo Scott Beck and Bryan Woods, 65 marks their largest film to date. Best known for their work on the script for the 2018 smash hit A Quiet Place, 65 may make audiences wonder how much of that success was Beck and Woods and how much of it was director John Krasinski. 65's stagnant script, halfhearted attempts at bonding the story's odd couple, and dodgy effects prove that the pair have a ways to go in developing their skills. With the exception of one incredibly well done scene with a giant Theropod, the movie lacks any sort of palpable suspense or real sense of danger. Thanks to both Adam Driver's bland acting and the duo's dull direction, any tense situation the characters find themselves in may lead to a sense of apathy from moviegoers; there's nothing in the film that makes them connect with Mills and Koa.

Overall, 65 is not a good movie by any stretch of the imagination. While the premise has a bit of interest to it, the writing and execution of said premise leave plenty to be desired. Adam Driver seems to almost be just going through the motions, turning in one of his weakest performances to date. Uninspired direction, shoddy visual effects, and subpar acting make this not one of the worst offerings of the year, but pretty damn close. A poor excuse for a reason to put dinosaurs and laser guns in the same setting, 65 feels like only 65 minutes were spent developing this film.

Quiet place writers + Adam Driver i expect a good history with Dinosaurs but was more like GeoStorm or Moonfall movies kinda chessy, at some times feels like a National Geo documentary and they just add humans on it!

I love Jurassic Park and feel like this movie it was going to be JP with Horror by the trailer i saw but didnt.

The Dino CGI sometimes looks like a videogame and didnt fit with the backround and theres a scene to save some budget they just focus the camara in a Holographic "gadget" and didnt feel acurate and right.

I really wish you enjoy this movie more than i do because i know a lot of People are JP fans.

review_title: Adam Driver vs dinosaurs and asteroids
review_detailed_main: This does exactly what it says on the tin - it's Adam Driver fighting a load of dinosaurs. The story is quite slight and not a huge amount happens in the 1 hour 30 minute run time, apart from Adam Driver fighting/running away from those dinosaurs. The relationship between the two main characters is sweet and the creature effects are good in the main (although I don't think any of the dinosaurs will be winning awards for their scientific accuracy!). All in all it's not brilliant, but it's not terrible either. So if you're looking for a nice easy watch that won't tax your brain any, this is the one for you.

review_title: Could've been great but the writers were mid
review_detailed_main:
If you're finding a good movie to sleep to, well this is the perfect one, seriously, there's no concrete plot and the only thing you'll see for the next minutes is adam driver shooting dinosaurs left and right. It's mid and the only thing that carried the whole movie is the jumpscares, adam's acting, the asteroid shot in the ending part and the handsome guy beside me inside the cinema.

But yeah seriously, if you want a sci-fi movie that'll hook and suspense the soul out of you, NEVER watch this one, it could've been damn great if the writers weren't the ones who wrote the quiet place lol, peace out.

And never mention the ending, got me "?"

I enjoyed this film way more than i thought i would. For the first time in a while i've seen a Hollywood film that isn't doing a political woke number in a action film but just lets a simple story go for it. Adam Driver and the young girls-his daughter and the only other survivor do a great job here of putting emotional punch into basically a survival story. I do think it was much better than the big budget Jurassic franchise because it was grounded in emotion. A father wanting to look after his children. It wasn't even over run with dinosaur scenes but they were well done anyway. Deserves a fair audience.

Atreeeeeeeyuuuuuuu!!!!

Kylo Ren and Ellie make their way across the planet Earth from 65 million years ago. There's a language barrier which isn't very well bridged. KOA made me think of camping, rv camping, coffee and Hawaii. (Kampgrounds of America... why is it a "k"? I don't No)

I love Adam Driver, he did a good job, as always. I'm a little surprised that he took this role as I was under the impression that he's rather selective.

The premise has high potential, but it just became a bit too predictable.

I'd like to see some more explanation for the cryogenically frozen bodies that just seemed to become defective upon crash-landing.

((Determined music playing)) ((Poignant music begins and ends))

The movie has a promising start, but then quickly goes downhill. Even Adam Driver looks like he was bored while filming.

Storywise, nothing really happens. Nothing is interesting.

Characters are dimensionless. There are only a few people and I didn't care for anyone.

Some parts are designed to be a horror movie but it is so silly and childish that looks like one of those cheap ones.

Music is the worst. It's supposed to elevate the scenes, not dominate them. Yet you hear constant "epic" music all around when literally nothing is happening on the screen. As a result, it quickly loses its meaning and effect.

Creature behaviors are unrealistic and usually don't make sense. Those parts reminded me of old video games with poor AI.

There's supposed to be humor somewhere, but it was just silly and out of place.

I won't even go into the scientific parts because the film makers obviously didn't care about it.

The whole movie is only 90 minutes but already felt like forever. I'd rather watch grass grow for 90 minutes. It would at least sooth my mind.

review_title: Routine dinoflick with very few dinosaurs

review_detailed_main:
It was decent escape for 90 minutes. I think the concept was cool and it looked great, but just sorta missed the mark.

There also seemed to be some "once out of the burning house" situations that had wondering "how did he get out of there?"

The special effects were really good and at times had me forgetting the creatures weren't actually real.

If you have an hour and a half to fill, this might be worthwhile. This movie had great potential and when I saw that it was only ninety minutes after reading the synopsis I figured it wouldn't be as good as I'd hoped.

As an aside, part of me hopes Earth archeological digs will find a 65 million year old space ship.

Once again another high octane trailer flatters to deceive - this mediocre sci-fi mash up of Jurassic Park meets After Earth fails to deliver on both it's concept and initial promise.

Adam Driver is decent enough as the film's Robinson Crusoe=esque lead and carries the entire load of the screenplay with vigour, but quite why the only other main human character in the film (Ariana Greenblatt) doesn't speak English is both pointless and absurd.

Of course, the real stars of the show are the numerous dinosaurs with good ole T-Rex taking centre stage. The survival/escape premise is simple enough and whille the cinematography and cgi effects are decent, the film lacks tension, pace and emotion, with plenty of plot holes that illicit more groans than a giant lizard stuck in the mud.

All in all then, what could've been a high-octane blockbuster is yet another disappointing damp squid that fails to ignite and gain lift-off. Oh well, beam me up Scotty...

review_title: 6.5 rating, a decent 90 minute sci-fi action movie
review_detailed_main:
